description: In April of 2016, the European Commission published a data protection package to reform, modernize and harmonize European data protection law. The cornerstone of the package is the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) which will replace the 1995 Data Protection Directive and, in the UK, the Data Protection Act 1998. This overview highlights the key themes of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) to help organizations understand the new legal framework in the EU. It is for those who have day-to-day responsibility for data protection.

00:25:29.156 --> 00:25:30.051
Still not bad.

511
00:25:30.051 --> 00:25:30.609
>> Say it's not so.

512
00:25:30.609 --> 00:25:31.466
Say it's not so.

513
00:25:31.466 --> 00:25:35.210
We are focused on money instead
of the rights of the individual.

514
00:25:35.210 --> 00:25:36.810
For shame Mike, for shame.

515
00:25:36.810 --> 00:25:37.605
>> Who would have thought.

516
00:25:37.605 --> 00:25:38.877
[LAUGH]
>> That is just absolutely,

00:25:38.877 --> 00:25:40.054
well absolutely correct.

518
00:25:40.054 --> 00:25:41.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> Unfortunately, right?

00:25:41.680 --> 00:25:43.140
All right, but that leaves the gate.

00:25:43.140 --> 00:25:44.570
So we make jokes about some of this stuff.

521
00:25:44.570 --> 00:25:48.960
But it is actually the case,
as unfortunate as it traditionally is.

522
00:25:48.960 --> 00:25:52.210
Not that every company is that way cause
many companies don't act that way.

523
00:25:52.210 --> 00:25:54.150
We wanna be fair and
we wanna be even-handed.

524
00:25:54.150 --> 00:25:57.920
But at the same time we do know and
see ample evidence of the fact

525
00:25:57.920 --> 00:26:00.620
that companies unfortunately,
at certain points in times,

526
00:26:00.620 --> 00:26:03.930
may make decisions based on
other mitigating factors,

527
00:26:03.930 --> 00:26:07.520
rather than just simply the rights and
protections of the individual.

528
00:26:07.520 --> 00:26:10.488
Whatever those mitigating or
other factors may be, money or

529
00:26:10.488 --> 00:26:13.409
any other factor, and
it's hard to say what they would be.

530
00:26:13.409 --> 00:26:16.817
But they don't always, unfortunately,
align with the rights of the individual,

531
00:26:16.817 --> 00:26:17.780
let's put it that way.

532
00:26:17.780 --> 00:26:20.500
As a general overview statement,
general rule,

533
00:26:20.500 --> 00:26:23.240
without specifying any one entity and
or any one reason,

534
00:26:23.240 --> 00:26:27.600
because it'll be unfair to identify
any one company that way, necessarily.

535
00:26:27.600 --> 00:26:28.330
But controllers and

536
00:26:28.330 --> 00:26:32.990

537
00:26:32.990 --> 00:26:38.000
And an approved certification may

538
00:26:38.000 --> 00:26:41.525
So for instance,
we may have certain certifications or

539
00:26:41.525 --> 00:26:45.500
codes of conduct in certain verticals or
silos industries that

00:26:45.500 --> 00:26:50.235

541
00:26:50.235 --> 00:26:52.860
Which is, again, pretty standard today.

542
00:26:52.860 --> 00:26:55.930
This may be something as easy

543
00:26:55.930 --> 00:27:01.170
to understand as perhaps

544
00:27:01.170 --> 00:27:06.680
For instance, the design specifications
to build our data centers and

545
00:27:06.680 --> 00:27:08.740
to validate their operation.

546
00:27:08.740 --> 00:27:13.950
ASHRAE, which is a group that's based in
the US but is known internationally for

547
00:27:13.950 --> 00:27:18.005
their ability to put
out standards to create

548
00:27:18.005 --> 00:27:22.765
the thought process on how to manage
the temperature conditions and

549
00:27:22.765 --> 00:27:25.815
the standardization of
a data center architecture.

550
00:27:25.815 --> 00:27:30.360
As well as the tiering,
the four-tier logical

551
00:27:30.360 --> 00:27:33.040
architecture levels we have when
we build out data centers, right?

552
00:27:33.040 --> 00:27:37.216
And all that stuff comes from
internationally recognized bodies that lay

553
00:27:37.216 --> 00:27:38.312
these things out.

554
00:27:38.312 --> 00:27:41.145
The IEEE that is responsible worldwide for

555
00:27:41.145 --> 00:27:47.055
most if not all of the standardization of
networking, capabilities and rules, right?

556
00:27:47.055 --> 00:27:51.054
The 802.3 working group for Ethernet,
although we don't often see it anymore and

557
00:27:51.054 --> 00:27:54.550
talk about it, [LAUGH] 802.5 for
token ring, things like that.

558
00:27:54.550 --> 00:27:55.480
ISO, right?

559
00:27:55.480 --> 00:27:58.280
For instance,
in the adherence to ISO standards,

560
00:27:58.280 --> 00:28:00.520
with regards to information security.

561
00:28:00.520 --> 00:28:05.130
ISO 27001, and 27002,
for instance, the ISMS,

562
00:28:05.130 --> 00:28:08.230
the Information Security Management System
standards.

563
00:28:08.230 --> 00:28:12.390
The actual breakdown of the logic
of the architecture and then 2702,

564
00:28:12.390 --> 00:28:15.460
the control factors and
counter measures associated with that.

565
00:28:15.460 --> 00:28:18.680
Any and all of these things,
if they're internationally recognized and

566
00:28:18.680 --> 00:28:22.580
accessible and
are applicable in this particular case

567
00:28:22.580 --> 00:28:24.860
can be put forward as
approved codes of conduct.

568
00:28:24.860 --> 00:28:28.100
Or prove certifications that
an entity can adhere to,

569
00:28:28.100 --> 00:28:31.150
if they can show alignment with them,
so that we can demonstrate compliance.

570
00:28:31.150 --> 00:28:33.884
So we're not saying anything new,
we want auditability,

571
00:28:33.884 --> 00:28:35.476
we want auditability standards.

572
00:28:35.476 --> 00:28:40.483
So the old SAS 70,
the more modern thought process that we're

573
00:28:40.483 --> 00:28:46.060
now using to update that the ISAE
standards that replace that, right?

574
00:28:46.060 --> 00:28:51.360
So the idea of the SOC level, SOC 1,
SOC 2, SOC 3, and just the auditability

575
00:28:51.360 --> 00:28:56.030
around information security management in
and financial reporting controls around

576
00:28:56.030 --> 00:29:00.450
that management in,
let's say some sort of a web environment.

577
00:29:00.450 --> 00:29:03.127
Those kinds of standards that
are internationally recognized and

578
00:29:03.127 --> 00:29:05.144
auditable can still be
used to prove compliance.

579
00:29:05.144 --> 00:29:08.215
It's just that we're enshrining
the idea of using them specifically for

580
00:29:08.215 --> 00:29:10.130
our controllers and processors here.

581
00:29:10.130 --> 00:29:13.680
So we do also have to have
documentation of the relationship

582
00:29:13.680 --> 00:29:17.030
between controllers and processors,
this is also very important.

583
00:29:17.030 --> 00:29:19.920
We have to have not only
documentation of it, but

584
00:29:19.920 --> 00:29:23.560
we have to have contracts that
mandate privacy obligations.

585
00:29:23.560 --> 00:29:26.160
I mentioned this idea of the PLA
just a couple of minutes ago.

586
00:29:26.160 --> 00:29:30.170
The Privacy Level Agreement, that's
lateral to and sits essentially aligned

587
00:29:30.170 --> 00:29:33.535
with the SLA, which most of you
are probably much more familiar with,

588
00:29:33.535 --> 00:29:35.320
the Service Level Agreement.

589
00:29:35.320 --> 00:29:38.664
But the idea of PLA has really gained
traction the last several years,

590
00:29:38.664 --> 00:29:41.963
especially with regards to cloud
services and cloud provisioning.

591
00:29:41.963 --> 00:29:44.596
And the idea of creating
a lateral document,

592
00:29:44.596 --> 00:29:49.727
a lateral contractual obligation between
provider and customer, that stipulates and

593
00:29:49.727 --> 00:29:53.955
lays out the rights associated for
privacy with regards to management,

594
00:29:53.955 --> 00:29:58.910
gathering, maintenance of and use of
customer data is what a PLA provides for.

595
00:29:58.910 --> 00:30:03.710
And so articles and artifacts like
that have to be mandated here for

596
00:30:03.710 --> 00:30:05.100
privacy obligations.

597
00:30:05.100 --> 00:30:08.240
But controllers ultimately
are on the hook,

598
00:30:08.240 --> 00:30:12.600
back to your point, to assure themselves
of the processor's privacy capabilities.

599
00:30:12.600 --> 00:30:16.170
In other words, it's the controller's
obligation in the relationship

600
00:30:16.170 --> 00:30:20.160
to figure out how to hold the processor
accountable to a standard and

601
00:30:20.160 --> 00:30:23.600
ensure that the processor
is following that standard.

602
00:30:23.600 --> 00:30:29.691
If they're not able to do that, then the
burden and the liability sits squarely,

603
00:30:29.691 --> 00:30:34.825
according to the GDPR,
sits squarely with the controller, right?

604
00:30:34.825 --> 00:30:36.461
The processor could screw it up and

605
00:30:36.461 --> 00:30:40.310
act in an illegal, inappropriate fashion,
and we'll hold them accountable.

606
00:30:40.310 --> 00:30:42.490
We'll find them,
we'll slap them on the wrist.

607
00:30:42.490 --> 00:30:45.050
But it's the controller that
bears ultimate responsibility in

608
00:30:45.050 --> 00:30:45.950
the relationship.

609
00:30:45.950 --> 00:30:50.890
To understand that that liability exists,
to document, manage and validate that and

610
00:30:50.890 --> 00:30:52.320
control that liability.

611
00:30:52.320 --> 00:30:54.960
And if it gets out of hand,
to then take action.

612
00:30:54.960 --> 00:30:57.790
So it's the controller who bears
responsibility there in order to

613
00:30:57.790 --> 00:30:58.480
assess that.

614
00:30:58.480 --> 00:31:00.230
So just wanna make sure
we're aware of that.

615
00:31:00.230 --> 00:31:03.070
I know we're almost out of time in this
episode, but on the heels of this,

616
00:31:03.070 --> 00:31:04.810
I mentioned fines in the last one.

617
00:31:04.810 --> 00:31:07.730
Just wanted to, since we're kinda talking
about responsibility and liability,

618
00:31:07.730 --> 00:31:10.800
thought it would be good to quickly talk
about the fines and enforcement piece.

619
00:31:10.800 --> 00:31:13.251
So we can see what some of
those clubs essentially,

620
00:31:13.251 --> 00:31:15.330
because they're over our heads, right?

621
00:31:15.330 --> 00:31:17.160
So I talk about fines and enforcement.

622
00:31:17.160 --> 00:31:21.000
Regulators I mentioned do have
an ability here to levy fines,

623
00:31:21.000 --> 00:31:21.940
pretty significant one.

624
00:31:22.975 --> 00:31:24.660
They're given legal authority, under GDPR,

625
00:31:24.660 --> 00:31:29.200
to issue penalties equal to
the greater of euro 10 million.

626
00:31:29.200 --> 00:31:31.350
So I mention,
this is a significant liability.

627
00:31:31.350 --> 00:31:34.318
10 million euros, which,
depending on the exchange rate,

628
00:31:34.318 --> 00:31:36.566
can significantly be be
a fair amount of money.

629
00:31:36.566 --> 00:31:41.363
Or 2%, 2%, of the entity's global gross
revenue for violations under GDPR, for

630
00:31:41.363 --> 00:31:44.976
things like record keeping,
security, breach notification,

631
00:31:44.976 --> 00:31:46.375
we'll talk about that.

632
00:31:46.375 --> 00:31:50.357
Really big deal if you have a breach and
don't notify in a timely manner,

633
00:31:50.357 --> 00:31:55.125
be an upcoming conversation, then you're
gonna rack up some significant fines, and

634
00:31:55.125 --> 00:31:57.435
privacy impact assessment obligation.

635
00:31:57.435 --> 00:32:01.830
So any and all of these areas
2% of global gross revenue or

636
00:32:01.830 --> 00:32:05.630
euro 10 million, the greater of the two.

637
00:32:05.630 --> 00:32:07.840
And for a large company,
let me underline and

638
00:32:07.840 --> 00:32:12.090
underscore that, not the equal,
less than, but greater than of the two.

639
00:32:12.090 --> 00:32:16.200
Which means yeah, 10 million euro that's a
lot of money, but for a big company 2% of

640
00:32:16.200 --> 00:32:20.410
gross revenue globally is gonna be
a lot more than 10 million euro, right.

641
00:32:20.410 --> 00:32:23.593
For a small company clearly 10 million
may break the bank and that's it.

642
00:32:23.593 --> 00:32:27.169
But for the Googles, the Microsofts,
the Amazons of the world,

643
00:32:27.169 --> 00:32:31.719
2% of the entity's gross global revenue is
gonna have a lot more zeros attached to

644
00:32:31.719 --> 00:32:34.987
that potentially than 10 million,
so that's an issue.

645
00:32:34.987 --> 00:32:37.271
>> I mean companies like
that they can write a,

646
00:32:37.271 --> 00:32:39.495
not that they wouldn't miss that money but

647
00:32:39.495 --> 00:32:43.970
it's not nearly the same impact when you
fine somebody like that 10 million euros.

648
00:32:43.970 --> 00:32:47.750
So it's good to see that they are thinking
about that when they levy these fines and

00:32:47.750 --> 00:32:51.130
they're like we're gonna make it so
that you don't go you know what,

00:32:51.130 --> 00:32:54.150
I know we might get fined but

00:32:54.150 --> 00:32:56.330
Cuz we see organizations do that now and
again.

00:32:56.330 --> 00:32:56.980
>> We do.
So

00:32:56.980 --> 00:32:59.650
that's level one,
that's essentially the first layer.

654
00:32:59.650 --> 00:33:04.190
But violations of obligations related to
legal justifications around processing,

655
00:33:04.190 --> 00:33:09.030
so things like did you get consent from
the data owner before you took their data.

656
00:33:09.030 --> 00:33:12.210
So if you go and
gather data under false pretenses,

657
00:33:12.210 --> 00:33:15.710
under the GDPR, without opting,
without consent of the owner,

658
00:33:15.710 --> 00:33:18.370
you're subject to a different
kind of fine, right.

659
00:33:18.370 --> 00:33:19.520
Data subject rights,

660
00:33:19.520 --> 00:33:23.450
you violate my rights as a data subject,
you gather my data without my permission,

661
00:33:23.450 --> 00:33:26.390
you use it in an inappropriate way
that I did not give you rights to.

662
00:33:26.390 --> 00:33:31.700
Or you expose it through
essentially unjustifiable behavior,

663
00:33:31.700 --> 00:33:34.925
you purposefully act in a way
that leads to data breach.

664
00:33:34.925 --> 00:33:38.920
And/or cross border data transfers,

665
00:33:38.920 --> 00:33:43.320
you send this data into an unprotected
area knowing you will expose it.

666
00:33:43.320 --> 00:33:47.825
Any of these actions or activities may
result in penalties of the greater, again

667
00:33:47.825 --> 00:33:52.620
greater, of the following euro 20 million
or 4% of the entity's gross revenue.

668
00:33:52.620 --> 00:33:53.270
>> Wow.

669
00:33:53.270 --> 00:33:56.865

essentially in phase one.

670
00:33:56.865 --> 00:34:00.551
Act inappropriately we're gonna slap
you on the wrist, purposefully,

671
00:34:00.551 --> 00:34:04.237
knowingly act in a way that exposes
data to confidentiality breach we're

672
00:34:04.237 --> 00:34:05.612

673
00:34:05.612 --> 00:34:06.146
>> Wow.

674
00:34:06.146 --> 00:34:09.885
>> So 4% of the gross revenue,
that's a significant amount of money.

00:34:38.233 --> 00:34:39.104
>> Yes, absolutely.

00:34:39.104 --> 00:34:39.882
>> Right.

693
00:34:39.882 --> 00:34:43.863
>> All right, well ladies and gentlemen,

00:34:43.863 --> 00:34:47.590
General Data Protection Regulation

We got a lot more good

00:34:59.768 --> 00:35:03.088

00:35:03.088 --> 00:35:06.200
So signing off for ITProTV,

There is language specifically, that does

an employee of the controller or

00:25:58.960 --> 00:25:59.860
So in other words, again,

expressly stated,
we actually can see an outsourcing.

00:26:03.380 --> 00:26:06.970
And you'll see this become a candidate for
as a service, right,

492
00:26:06.970 --> 00:26:07.910
whatever that would be called.

493
00:26:07.910 --> 00:26:09.060
And we have that already.

Managed security service providers,
MSSPs essentially fall into this category,

495
00:26:13.906 --> 00:26:17.741
although the focus is much more

496
00:26:17.741 --> 00:26:21.047
But broadly, you're outsourcing
Security as a Service, SECaaS,

497
00:26:21.047 --> 00:26:24.125

all things that go under that,

498
00:26:24.125 --> 00:26:27.499
this could be a subset of that, and

00:26:27.499 --> 00:26:31.660
That there like two shares in

00:26:31.660 --> 00:26:35.755
those kind of service entities that

00:26:35.755 --> 00:26:39.519

00:26:39.519 --> 00:26:41.790

The IBMs, the Hewlett Packards of
the world, all the services entities,

00:26:45.275 --> 00:26:46.282
Dell etc., right.

00:26:46.282 --> 00:26:49.250
They're all doing this kind of work and

506
00:26:49.250 --> 00:26:50.919
I mean, this is not new, but

the focus specifically in this

00:27:03.511 --> 00:27:07.114
And broadening that scope and
then narrowing the focus with regards

00:27:16.690 --> 00:27:20.320

517

What about privacy matter?

Regulation mandate's

00:27:26.442 --> 00:27:29.975

appropriate organizational controls have

00:27:33.795 --> 00:27:36.385

00:27:36.385 --> 00:27:39.865
Which is not unusual, and not,
it's essentially the norm today.

00:27:39.865 --> 00:27:41.495

00:27:52.580 --> 00:27:57.600
And the idea of understanding that return

00:27:57.600 --> 00:28:01.370

00:28:01.370 --> 00:28:04.683
A business impact assessment to rate and

offerings in the company unless

A risk value to them for a variety of

00:28:33.730 --> 00:28:37.720

00:28:43.520 --> 00:28:45.140
Security, early and often, right?

00:28:45.140 --> 00:28:50.570
The earlier you break down the pieces

545
00:28:50.570 --> 00:28:54.520
the system or software development life
cycle, the better off the outcomes are.

546
00:28:54.520 --> 00:28:57.470

547

More likely you are in other

You wanna be thinking

Because these are all parts of what we

00:30:30.580 --> 00:30:33.459
What you call a significant risk

576
00:30:33.459 --> 00:30:34.792

00:30:34.792 --> 00:30:39.012
But with regards to ensuring that we have,

00:30:49.860 --> 00:30:52.510

Or, through inactivity, you make

I consent is perfectly fine.

That's a very important thought process,

that word explicit can send, right?

Get out your checkbook because

the user of the data subject must
understand what they are consenting to

122
00:06:20.379 --> 00:06:25.590
when they give consent explicitly

00:06:25.590 --> 00:06:28.580
Otherwise, there's disconnect and

00:06:28.580 --> 00:06:33.350
Because again, what you often see is

00:06:33.350 --> 00:06:37.220
as a result, our data gets used in all

00:06:37.220 --> 00:06:38.470

00:06:38.470 --> 00:06:42.780
Or it was so obtuse and
the obfuscation and the legalese and

00:06:42.780 --> 00:06:46.590

00:06:46.590 --> 00:06:49.850

00:06:49.850 --> 00:06:51.900
And that is unfortunately been the case.

131
00:06:51.900 --> 00:06:52.740
>> Yes.
>> And so we're really

00:06:52.740 --> 00:06:56.330

00:06:56.330 --> 00:07:00.380
So the idea is that it must be obvious

134
00:07:00.380 --> 00:07:01.490

135
00:07:01.490 --> 00:07:05.876
You can't tack it on later and tell me

00:07:05.876 --> 00:07:10.200

00:07:10.200 --> 00:07:12.960
We may say, hey,
in addition we need something else.

00:07:12.960 --> 00:07:17.160
Well, we gotta go back and reconsent

00:07:17.160 --> 00:07:21.270
And if they opt out, remember,
we have a right to be forgotten, right?

140
00:07:21.270 --> 00:07:24.505
If they opt out,
then that data is no longer useable.

141
00:07:24.505 --> 00:07:27.725
So it is important, because now we
have this requirement to refresh and

142
00:07:27.725 --> 00:07:30.565
update, when services or needs change, and

143
00:07:30.565 --> 00:07:33.565
to re-opt the data subject,
in order to do that.

144
00:07:33.565 --> 00:07:36.005
Consent should be demonstrable,
as I talked about, right?

145
00:07:36.005 --> 00:07:39.535
We need to be able to show
clearly how consent was gained,

146
00:07:39.535 --> 00:07:41.685
as the organization gathering the data.

147
00:07:41.685 --> 00:07:43.185
Consent must be freely given,

148
00:07:43.185 --> 00:07:47.500
no coercion on the part of
the organization against the data subject.

149
00:07:47.500 --> 00:07:49.451
Offering chocolate is

150
00:07:49.451 --> 00:07:52.477
>> [LAUGH]
>> But no coercion of any kind, right?

151
00:07:52.477 --> 00:07:56.660
So in other words,
you can't insist that they opt in and

00:07:56.660 --> 00:08:00.940
give consent in order to be

153
00:08:00.940 --> 00:08:04.435
And, hey, if you don't do this, wow, we're
gonna Kill all of your other accounts and

00:08:04.435 --> 00:08:05.061
get rid of you.

155
00:08:05.061 --> 00:08:07.285
No, this is something that you
can't coerce someone into.

156
00:08:07.285 --> 00:08:09.030
So it has to be freely given.

157
00:08:09.030 --> 00:08:11.220
Withdrawing consent should
always be possible, right?

158
00:08:11.220 --> 00:08:13.170
In other words,
you should make it as easy for

159
00:08:13.170 --> 00:08:16.795
the data subject to withdraw their

160
00:08:16.795 --> 00:08:19.925
Because again,
what often happens is you opt in and

161
00:08:19.925 --> 00:08:24.405

162
00:08:24.405 --> 00:08:25.395
Yeah, good luck, right?

00:08:25.395 --> 00:08:26.425
I mean, that's never happening.

164
00:08:26.425 --> 00:08:30.435
You might as well change your name,

165
00:08:30.435 --> 00:08:34.710
So the problem becomes that it's easy to

166
00:08:34.710 --> 00:08:35.440
It is.

167
00:08:35.440 --> 00:08:36.410
We're leveling the playing field.

168
00:08:36.410 --> 00:08:39.500
The GDPR says look, you make it easy for
them to consent and

169
00:08:39.500 --> 00:08:41.860
you better make it easy for
them to opt out.

170
00:08:41.860 --> 00:08:45.610
Because they may want to do that and
when they do, it better be as easy for

171
00:08:45.610 --> 00:08:48.280
them to do that- them being
the data subject, the customer,

172
00:08:48.280 --> 00:08:51.090
who owns the data- as it was for
them to opt in.

173
00:08:51.090 --> 00:08:54.490
Or you're out of business, because you're
obviously not operating the right way.

174
00:08:55.740 --> 00:08:59.850
Information provided at data collection
must be made freely available to the data

175
00:08:59.850 --> 00:09:03.420
subject when they are in need to see it.

176
00:09:03.420 --> 00:09:08.430
So, in other words,
we have to understand as data subjects

177
00:09:08.430 --> 00:09:12.010

178
00:09:12.010 --> 00:09:15.135
But we have the right to understand what

179
00:09:15.135 --> 00:09:18.678

180
00:09:18.678 --> 00:09:22.250
The identity and the contact details
of the controller and the DPO,

181
00:09:22.250 --> 00:09:25.340
the data protection officer,
should be made available.

182
00:09:25.340 --> 00:09:27.660
So the data protection
officer has to be registered.

183
00:09:27.660 --> 00:09:31.780
We, as the consumer, as the data subject,
should be able to contact.

184
00:09:31.780 --> 00:09:33.330
Remember, they become
the point of contact,

185
00:09:33.330 --> 00:09:36.800
as we talked about, for any grievances or
concerns that we may have.

186
00:09:36.800 --> 00:09:39.310
We should be able to freely and
easily understand who they are and

187
00:09:39.310 --> 00:09:41.140
be in touch with them if necessary.

188
00:09:41.140 --> 00:09:44.690
Of the purposes of the process in
which personal data Is intended.

189
00:09:44.690 --> 00:09:46.990
Again that should have been
part of the opt-in clause, but

190
00:09:46.990 --> 00:09:49.960
we should be able to be reminded
of that at any point in time.

191
00:09:49.960 --> 00:09:51.850
The legal basis of the processing,

192
00:09:51.850 --> 00:09:54.980
under what law requirements are they
gathering and processing the data.

193
00:09:54.980 --> 00:09:57.590
Where applicable, legal interest or

194
00:09:57.590 --> 00:10:00.270
legitimate interest pursued
by the controller or

195
00:10:00.270 --> 00:10:04.170
the third party acting as the processor
that they have handed of to?

196
00:10:04.170 --> 00:10:08.510
Where applicable, recipients or
categories of recipients of this data.

197
00:10:08.510 --> 00:10:10.290
Again, who's gonna get my data?

198
00:10:10.290 --> 00:10:14.250
Wells Fargo, Citibank got it initially but
who are they sharing with, right?

199
00:10:14.250 --> 00:10:16.220
I wanna know,
they're giving it to a mortgage company.

200
00:10:16.220 --> 00:10:18.280
They're giving it to
a financial services firm.

201
00:10:18.280 --> 00:10:22.310
They're giving it to an insurance
company owned by them as a subsidiary or

202
00:10:22.310 --> 00:10:24.380
through some sort of
contractual arrangement.

203
00:10:24.380 --> 00:10:28.750
And I wanna know that, and I'm entitled
to know that as the data subject.

204
00:10:28.750 --> 00:10:32.159
Again, I'm thinking about picking up and
moving to-

205
00:10:32.159 --> 00:10:33.120
>> [LAUGH]

206
00:10:33.120 --> 00:10:33.980
>> I'm going over there.

207
00:10:33.980 --> 00:10:35.840
I'm-
>> I'm sitting here the whole time

208
00:10:35.840 --> 00:10:39.700
thinking, when are we getting this and

209
00:10:39.700 --> 00:10:42.803
>> Not with the political circus going

210
00:10:42.803 --> 00:10:43.372
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

211
00:10:43.372 --> 00:10:46.630
the reality is the protections afforded,
and I made this clear in the first

212
00:10:46.630 --> 00:10:49.900
episode, and I've said this in one form or
another in every episode so far.

213
00:10:49.900 --> 00:10:55.435
The protections afforded under
the EU's multigenerational,

214
00:10:55.435 --> 00:11:00.430
multi-decade-long march towards protection
of the rights of the individual

215
00:11:00.430 --> 00:11:04.060
in all the forms that they've taken up

00:11:04.060 --> 00:11:09.020
through the GDPR, are very far ahead
in almost every case without exception.

217
00:11:09.020 --> 00:11:12.560
Very far ahead of almost
every other area and

218
00:11:12.560 --> 00:11:14.960
country's pursuit of this in those areas.

219
00:11:14.960 --> 00:11:16.790
I mean this is really the gold standard.

220
00:11:16.790 --> 00:11:19.010
We don't often get to say that and
really mean it.

221
00:11:19.010 --> 00:11:20.260
But, these sets of rules and

222
00:11:20.260 --> 00:11:23.360
laws really set a bar that is not
matched anywhere in the world today.

223
00:11:23.360 --> 00:11:25.355
>> Absolutely.
>> And that is important to know, right?

224
00:11:25.355 --> 00:11:29.730
Where applicable, if we do plan on
transferring data as the data control,

225
00:11:29.730 --> 00:11:32.280
we have to make the subject aware of that,
as well.

226
00:11:32.280 --> 00:11:34.540
The period for
which personal data will be stored.

227
00:11:34.540 --> 00:11:38.610
Or if we can't definitively say that,
the criteria used to determine the period.

228
00:11:38.610 --> 00:11:42.070
So in other words, we may not be able

229
00:11:42.070 --> 00:11:44.740
because of tax requirements

00:11:44.740 --> 00:11:46.770
So we can say that, for

00:11:46.770 --> 00:11:50.680
We have a law, federal law in the US
that says, records, business-related

00:11:50.680 --> 00:11:54.770

At the end of seven years

00:11:56.580 --> 00:11:58.191
Germany has ten years, for instance.

00:11:58.191 --> 00:12:00.085
It varies by country.

00:12:00.085 --> 00:12:03.033
So we could say that under this law,
or we could say,

237
00:12:03.033 --> 00:12:05.890
we're not sure of the data
retention period.

238
00:12:05.890 --> 00:12:10.359
It will be based on the current laws in

00:12:10.359 --> 00:12:11.611
because it may vary.

00:12:11.611 --> 00:12:16.010
We're a global company and every country

00:12:16.010 --> 00:12:19.730
It will vary by country but we will adhere

00:12:19.730 --> 00:12:24.330
the legality of operation or the feeder

00:12:24.330 --> 00:12:25.330
And that would satisfy.

00:12:25.330 --> 00:12:26.550
That would be appropriate.

00:12:26.550 --> 00:12:27.490
So we do have an opt-in,

00:12:27.490 --> 00:12:31.330
in that respect there,

00:12:31.330 --> 00:12:34.730
Not because we purposely want to obfuscate

00:12:34.730 --> 00:12:39.190
but rather, to make it easy for businesses
to understand how to comply without being,

249
00:12:39.190 --> 00:12:42.780
you know producing a volume of
regulatory explanation that's 1,000

00:12:42.780 --> 00:12:45.010
pages that nobody's
gonna understand anyway.

251
00:12:45.010 --> 00:12:46.100
You mean, I'm in Uzbekistan.

00:12:46.100 --> 00:12:48.630
Let me look that up in
table five in the back,

253
00:12:48.630 --> 00:12:52.888
and let me see in five point
text what that looks like.

254
00:12:52.888 --> 00:12:54.613
That just doesn't work, right?

255
00:12:54.613 --> 00:12:58.030
We have to obviously make this
burden realistic for both parties.

256
00:12:58.030 --> 00:13:00.230
It's kind of what the balancing
thought process is.

257
00:13:00.230 --> 00:13:02.410
If possible, obviously, as we said,

258
00:13:02.410 --> 00:13:05.520
figuring out what the criteria would
be as opposed to the actual statement.

259
00:13:05.520 --> 00:13:08.900
The existence of the right to access,
rectify, erase personal data.

260
00:13:08.900 --> 00:13:10.530
I talked about this, very important.

261
00:13:10.530 --> 00:13:13.500
The right to data portability,
the right to withdraw consent,

262
00:13:13.500 --> 00:13:15.490
as I suggested, at any time.

263
00:13:15.490 --> 00:13:18.680
And the right to complain with a
supervisory authority, if something is not

264
00:13:18.680 --> 00:13:22.470
right, and that proper channels have been
followed but you have had no redress.

265
00:13:22.470 --> 00:13:25.279
Meaning, you have the right and
the responsibility,

266
00:13:25.279 --> 00:13:28.660
as a data subject,
to maintain the integrity of your data.

267
00:13:28.660 --> 00:13:31.140
And if the company doesn't do that,
you can call them on it.

268
00:13:31.140 --> 00:13:32.610
And you can find out if that's the case.

269
00:13:32.610 --> 00:13:34.270
You can ask them to address it.

270
00:13:34.270 --> 00:13:36.320
And they have a legal
responsibility to do so.

271
00:13:36.320 --> 00:13:38.160
And there's a framework set up for that.

272
00:13:38.160 --> 00:13:41.490
We'll get into that in more detail
as we talk about the eight specific

273
00:13:41.490 --> 00:13:44.390
rights created for
individuals under the GDPR,

274
00:13:44.390 --> 00:13:47.110
and examine each of them
in upcoming conversations.

275
00:13:47.110 --> 00:13:49.210
But you have a right to do that.

276
00:13:49.210 --> 00:13:52.620
The company also has responsibilities and
rights in that regard.

277
00:13:52.620 --> 00:13:56.490
They have 30 days on average, one month,
to respond to a normal request.

278
00:13:56.490 --> 00:13:57.810
Nothing out of the ordinary.

279
00:13:57.810 --> 00:14:01.730
If it's a more complex request, they can
extend that and say, you know, look,

280
00:14:01.730 --> 00:14:03.060
we need more time.

281
00:14:03.060 --> 00:14:05.350
Here's notification
that we need more time.

282
00:14:05.350 --> 00:14:08.910
And we can get up to another
two months to deal with that.

283
00:14:08.910 --> 00:14:10.540
But then they have to respond.

284
00:14:10.540 --> 00:14:14.420
Under certain circumstances, they can
actually choose to ignore that request.

285
00:14:14.420 --> 00:14:17.600
I'm not saying that that would always
be appropriate, quite the opposite.

286
00:14:17.600 --> 00:14:21.050
But there are certain categories
of requests where they actually,

287
00:14:21.050 --> 00:14:24.900
as the processor and the controller,
have the legal right under the GDPR to

288
00:14:24.900 --> 00:14:28.200
essentially ignore that request and
say, sorry we're not complying.

289
00:14:28.200 --> 00:14:33.040
They have to produce documentation to that
effect if they're called up on a complaint

290
00:14:33.040 --> 00:14:35.670
before the Supervisory Authority
like I'm suggesting,

291
00:14:35.670 --> 00:14:38.660
because they could decide to ignore you,
that doesn't mean they're right.

292
00:14:38.660 --> 00:14:40.300
And you could be pissed off
at that they're ignoring you,

293
00:14:40.300 --> 00:14:41.460
that doesn't mean you're right.

294
00:14:41.460 --> 00:14:43.940
And somebody who is impartial
has to decide that.

295
00:14:43.940 --> 00:14:46.340
That's what the supervisory
authority is for.

296
00:14:46.340 --> 00:14:48.740
So you have the ability
to go escalate this and

297
00:14:48.740 --> 00:14:50.680
complain to an impartial third party.

298
00:14:50.680 --> 00:14:56.270
And then based on the circumstances and
the applicability of the GDPR regulations,

299
00:14:56.270 --> 00:15:00.280
you may or may not have the ability
to get some sort of satisfaction.

300
00:15:00.280 --> 00:15:02.940
But very clear, and
we'll talk more about this later,

301
00:15:02.940 --> 00:15:06.490
there are specifically carved out
categories where the controller and

302
00:15:06.490 --> 00:15:10.000
processor have the legal
right to ignore a request.

303
00:15:10.000 --> 00:15:11.910
And they can go to
the supervisory authority,

304
00:15:11.910 --> 00:15:14.540
produce documentation to that effect,
and essentially be told,

305
00:15:14.540 --> 00:15:16.900
it's okay, forget about it,
you don't have to respond.

306
00:15:16.900 --> 00:15:18.420
But under most circumstances,

307
00:15:18.420 --> 00:15:22.300
they have a legal requirement
to respond in a timely fashion.

308
00:15:22.300 --> 00:15:23.740
That is the language used.

309
00:15:23.740 --> 00:15:25.570
And a timely fashion is
defined as one month.

310
00:15:25.570 --> 00:15:30.670
And then there's an extension period based
on complexity of request, including,

311
00:15:30.670 --> 00:15:33.410
by the way,
complexity is defined as many things.

312
00:15:33.410 --> 00:15:37.690
But repetition of the request
is also considered complexity.

313
00:15:37.690 --> 00:15:39.630
Meaning hey,
they didn't do it the first time,

314
00:15:39.630 --> 00:15:42.150
let me go slam them with
five other requests.

315
00:15:42.150 --> 00:15:45.890
That then becomes a more complex issue and
they can actually ask for

316
00:15:45.890 --> 00:15:46.990
more time to deal with it.

317
00:15:46.990 --> 00:15:49.920
And make it to the point where under
the nuisance thought process they may

318
00:15:49.920 --> 00:15:50.970
be able to ignore it.

319
00:15:50.970 --> 00:15:53.530
So you have to understand
where you stand here,

320
00:15:53.530 --> 00:15:57.183
both as the data subject as well as
as a controller and or processor.

321
00:15:57.183 --> 00:15:58.373
It's very important to know that.

322
00:15:58.373 --> 00:16:02.691
Where the data's not been obtained
directly from the data subject But rather,

323
00:16:02.691 --> 00:16:04.503
maybe from a third party entity.

324
00:16:04.503 --> 00:16:07.127
So if I come to you and
I collect your data directly,

325
00:16:07.127 --> 00:16:11.218
there's a different set of rules and
expectations involved where I'm dealing

326
00:16:11.218 --> 00:16:14.160
with you as the processor
directly as a data subject.

327
00:16:14.160 --> 00:16:17.035
Than if I I inherit your
data from somewhere else and

328
00:16:17.035 --> 00:16:18.565
I never talk to you directly.

329
00:16:18.565 --> 00:16:20.140
I'm just getting it,
the company passed it to company B.

330
00:16:20.140 --> 00:16:21.190
>> Right.

331
00:16:21.190 --> 00:16:22.545
>> Or essentially, right?

332
00:16:22.545 --> 00:16:26.345
So then we have to understand and
be told, where we got the data,

333
00:16:26.345 --> 00:16:27.320
where did it come from.

334
00:16:27.320 --> 00:16:30.242
So you have to tell me as a company
that I never talked to you,

335
00:16:30.242 --> 00:16:31.592
hey how'd you get my phone number?

336
00:16:31.592 --> 00:16:33.052
Who are you, why are you talking to me?

337
00:16:33.052 --> 00:16:34.692
I got this from company x.

338
00:16:34.692 --> 00:16:39.102
You gave them your data and you gave them
the right to give it to a partner for

339
00:16:39.102 --> 00:16:40.172
whatever reasons.

340
00:16:40.172 --> 00:16:41.266
That's where I'm getting it from.

341
00:16:41.266 --> 00:16:42.926
They have to be able to tell you that.

342
00:16:42.926 --> 00:16:45.476
Also, the existence of any profiling and

343
00:16:47.676 --> 00:16:51.136
meaningful information and
logic about the information.

344
00:16:51.136 --> 00:16:52.536
Meaning, essentially metadata, right?

345
00:16:52.536 --> 00:16:54.276
So we have to make sure
we're aware of that.

346
00:16:55.320 --> 00:16:57.740
And that we do understand
that there may be times,

347
00:16:57.740 --> 00:17:01.030
where there's other data that's
been gathered and/or created.

348
00:17:01.030 --> 00:17:03.900
And we have an ability to see and
understand that as well.

349
00:17:03.900 --> 00:17:07.960
There are exceptions as I suggested
where effort would be considered to be

350
00:17:07.960 --> 00:17:11.690
disproportionate and where
the information has already been provided

351
00:17:11.690 --> 00:17:14.530
to the data subject,

352
00:17:14.530 --> 00:17:16.810
So if this is something
we've already done for

353
00:17:16.810 --> 00:17:19.030
you, then we may not have to do it again.

354
00:17:19.030 --> 00:17:21.742
If the effort to do so
is disproportionately large,

355
00:17:21.742 --> 00:17:24.960
defined disproportionately large,
it's a sliding scale.

356
00:17:24.960 --> 00:17:27.600
There is no clear definition that
if it took this amount of time,

357
00:17:27.600 --> 00:17:30.880
it would be acceptable, but if it took
that amount of time, it would not.

358
00:17:30.880 --> 00:17:32.250
Again, a lot of this is vague.

359
00:17:32.250 --> 00:17:34.080
I mean this is how laws are written,
right?

360
00:17:34.080 --> 00:17:37.602
They're not step-by-step process
cookbooks that tell you what to do.

361
00:17:37.602 --> 00:17:41.989
They're high level statements of intent
that direct us towards some sort of lofty,

362
00:17:41.989 --> 00:17:45.860
and usually more often than not,
hopefully important common goals.

363
00:17:45.860 --> 00:17:49.550
And the implementation details
are often dealt with separately, right?

364
00:17:49.550 --> 00:17:52.040
That's where we get into other things.

365
00:17:52.040 --> 00:17:53.610
So we just gotta understand,

366
00:17:53.610 --> 00:17:56.360
that when we say something
like disproportionate effort,

367
00:17:56.360 --> 00:17:59.340
it's hard to say for sure what that
would really be categorized as, right?

368
00:17:59.340 --> 00:18:03.070
But we do know that there is
some language to that effect.

369
00:18:03.070 --> 00:18:04.660
I just wanna make sure
we're aware of that.

370
00:18:04.660 --> 00:18:06.780
What about profiling, right?

371
00:18:06.780 --> 00:18:10.820
We talked about consent, but the profiling
is also called out and part of this.

372
00:18:10.820 --> 00:18:14.888
Any automated processing of personal
data to determine certain criteria about

373
00:18:14.888 --> 00:18:17.250
a person is considered to be profiling.

374
00:18:17.250 --> 00:18:19.120
Quoting, again quoting, right?

375
00:18:19.120 --> 00:18:24.430
In particular to analyze or predict
aspects concerning the natural persons

376
00:18:24.430 --> 00:18:29.525
performance at work, economic situation,
health, personal preferences, interest,

377
00:18:29.525 --> 00:18:33.000
reliability behavior,
location or movements.

378
00:18:33.000 --> 00:18:37.640
Any of that falls under the guise of and
categorized as profiling.

379
00:18:37.640 --> 00:18:40.100
So we just wanna make sure that
we're thinking about that.

380
00:18:40.100 --> 00:18:43.170
Individuals have the right not
to be subject to the results

381
00:18:43.170 --> 00:18:44.460
of automated decision making.

382
00:18:44.460 --> 00:18:48.760
That's one of the eight guaranteed rights
under the GDPR, including profiling.

383
00:18:48.760 --> 00:18:50.569
So essentially we can opt out, right?

384
00:18:50.569 --> 00:18:53.540
We do have the right as
a data subject to opt out.

385
00:18:53.540 --> 00:18:54.750
And so we do need to be aware of that.

386
00:18:54.750 --> 00:18:55.770
Again, it's one of those eight rights.

387
00:18:55.770 --> 00:18:58.110
We'll talk more about those
in upcoming conversations.

388
00:18:58.110 --> 00:19:02.686
But automated decision making can get
a company into trouble because they don't

389
00:19:02.686 --> 00:19:04.780
have the consent of the individual.

390
00:19:04.780 --> 00:19:08.587
They may not be able to use the data or
take those actions if they can not be

391
00:19:08.587 --> 00:19:12.610
proven to have been derived from
some sort of consensual activity.

392
00:19:12.610 --> 00:19:17.460
So for instance here, just hypothetically,
think about how for instance today,

393
00:19:17.460 --> 00:19:22.920
loans are gonna be granted or
denied at least in the United States and

394
00:19:22.920 --> 00:19:25.610
many other countries around the world
based on the variety of factors.

395
00:19:25.610 --> 00:19:29.340
Credit rating, credit worthiness,
your ability to repay the loan,

396
00:19:29.340 --> 00:19:31.660
collateral you may be able to provide,
all these things, right?

397
00:19:31.660 --> 00:19:34.360
You'll have your paid loans off in
the past, by the time you get a loan,

398
00:19:34.360 --> 00:19:37.530
have you essentially welched on it and
never paid it back.

399
00:19:37.530 --> 00:19:39.560
So but
there's a lot of automatic profile and

400
00:19:39.560 --> 00:19:41.930
decision making that goes into this,
right?

401
00:19:41.930 --> 00:19:45.990
Now it would still be legal to do all
this as a company as long as the data

402
00:19:45.990 --> 00:19:49.890
you're using has been consented
to by the data subject upfront.

403
00:19:49.890 --> 00:19:53.940
Meaning, hey, I consented for
you to have access to my bank records.

404
00:19:53.940 --> 00:19:58.000
I consented for
you to keep track of my payment history

405
00:19:58.000 --> 00:20:00.640
by agreeing to the terms of
service to use a credit card, and

406
00:20:00.640 --> 00:20:03.270
paying back my car loan, and
whatever else you can think of.

407
00:20:03.270 --> 00:20:07.823
And so as a result, we can then take that
data, run it through an algorithm or

408
00:20:07.823 --> 00:20:10.829
whatever magic we use behind the scenes,
right?

409
00:20:10.829 --> 00:20:12.553
Little guys in room with darts
throwing stuff at a wall.

410
00:20:12.553 --> 00:20:13.963
>> [LAUGH]
>> Whatever it may be.

411
00:20:13.963 --> 00:20:17.526
And as a result, you know we can then
derive, ding, ding, ding, right,

412
00:20:17.526 --> 00:20:21.225
an answer that says yes, give Mike this
money, or what, are you kidding me?

413
00:20:21.225 --> 00:20:23.200
>> [LAUGH]
>> You never give him anything, right?

414
00:20:23.200 --> 00:20:26.950
And we can do that because we have
consent for the use of that data.

415
00:20:26.950 --> 00:20:31.060
But if we don't have consent for
all that, then it's no longer allowed.

416
00:20:31.060 --> 00:20:36.060
So there's a lot of subtle interpretation
that has to go on here because we have to

417
00:20:36.060 --> 00:20:41.270
understand what automatic decision making
and profiling may or not be classified as.

418
00:20:41.270 --> 00:20:43.440
And that may not be very easy.

419
00:20:43.440 --> 00:20:48.710
We do have to also understand that
member states do have the ability

420
00:20:48.710 --> 00:20:53.360
to potentially allow things like
profiling on an as needed per case basis.

421
00:20:53.360 --> 00:20:57.470
So the law may say hey no,
but then France may say,

422
00:20:57.470 --> 00:20:59.540
no we're gonna do profiling
under these conditions.

423
00:20:59.540 --> 00:21:02.260
And they have the right as
a member state to go out and

424
00:21:02.260 --> 00:21:04.170
carve out some exceptions
in certain areas.

425
00:21:04.170 --> 00:21:07.510
So that also may happen and
that may be part of what goes on.

426
00:21:07.510 --> 00:21:09.210
So we just have to think about that.

427
00:21:09.210 --> 00:21:13.020
Things like direct marketing and
legitimate interest have to be considered.

428
00:21:13.020 --> 00:21:17.740
We do recognize that the processing
of data for direct marketing purposes

429
00:21:17.740 --> 00:21:21.490
is considered to be a legitimate interest,
since I was hinting at it, suggesting.

430
00:21:21.490 --> 00:21:24.320
We're not trying to shoot business in
the foot and say you can't market,

431
00:21:24.320 --> 00:21:25.270
you can't do anything.

432
00:21:25.270 --> 00:21:28.720
We're just try to constrain activities so
that they happen in a way

433
00:21:28.720 --> 00:21:32.552
that is informed, consensual, and
therefore fair for both parties.

434
00:21:32.552 --> 00:21:34.665
So that's part of what
we think about here and

435
00:21:34.665 --> 00:21:36.845
legitimate interest is one
of the grounds for consent.

436
00:21:36.845 --> 00:21:38.845
Meaning company markets to you and

437
00:21:38.845 --> 00:21:42.355
you consent to the use of your
data under that particular guise.

438
00:21:42.355 --> 00:21:45.075
Then essentially,
they're allowed to do these things,

439
00:21:45.075 --> 00:21:47.605
because they've asked you and
you said yes.

440
00:21:47.605 --> 00:21:51.945
But if they send you an email or
in the mail, hard mail,

441
00:21:51.945 --> 00:21:54.365
snail mail,
they send you a flyer or whatever.

442
00:21:54.365 --> 00:21:56.395
And you call the phone number or
you go the website,

443
00:21:56.395 --> 00:22:00.090
you opt in,
then you can't blame them, right?

444
00:22:00.090 --> 00:22:01.770
You made an informed decision.

445
00:22:01.770 --> 00:22:03.840
So you gotta think about that,
and just understand that.

446
00:22:03.840 --> 00:22:07.920
Because that is, again, as long as
they apply the principles of fair and

447
00:22:07.920 --> 00:22:10.870
lawful data collection and
processing and protection,

448
00:22:10.870 --> 00:22:15.090
as defined under the GDPR, the business

449
00:22:15.090 --> 00:22:17.110
they are lawful, and
they are doing the right things.

450
00:22:18.290 --> 00:22:19.120
so we do need and

451
00:22:19.120 --> 00:22:23.880
specifically define lawful processing as
being criteria but that would be accepted.

452
00:22:23.880 --> 00:22:28.130
Now, also keep in mind, there are some
overrides for that as I suggested.

One of them is this area of

454
00:22:31.030 --> 00:22:34.683
which is a big area, big concern

455
00:22:34.683 --> 00:22:37.776
And so, we do need to be aware of that,
because again, and

456
00:22:37.776 --> 00:22:42.199
quoting the exact language, the access
that the process is considered lawful if,

457

quoting here, right, quoting.

465
00:22:55.710 --> 00:23:00.510
Processing is lawful if processing is
necessary for the purposes of legitimate

interest pursued by the controller or by

Except this is the part

468

freedoms of the data subject.

470
00:23:12.085 --> 00:23:14.235
Which require protection of personal data,

471
00:23:14.235 --> 00:23:18.035

472
00:23:18.035 --> 00:23:22.695
So, there are cases where, when we collect
certain kinds of data from certain

473
00:23:22.695 --> 00:23:27.005

then the same rules may not apply.

474
00:23:27.005 --> 00:23:29.690
Children are definitely
a defined protected category.

475
00:23:29.690 --> 00:23:33.270
And when we market to them, when we
deal with them, let's say, online for

like it or not, is a reality today, right?

477
00:23:37.410 --> 00:23:42.480
We have to understand that there has to
be a minimum acceptable age for opt in.

478
00:23:42.480 --> 00:23:44.700
Currently, that age is
defined as being 16 or

479
00:23:44.700 --> 00:23:48.860

for member states to go down

480

through their own overrides,
as I suggested, to as low as 13.

481
00:23:52.430 --> 00:23:56.573
So a member state can opt out and
say, hey, we understand the bar and

482
00:23:56.573 --> 00:24:00.662

that it's 13 in our country.

483
00:24:00.662 --> 00:24:04.311

they pass an exception legally through

484
00:24:04.311 --> 00:24:07.180

declare that formally.

485
00:24:07.180 --> 00:24:09.501
But it cannot go below 13
according to the GDPR,

486
00:24:09.501 --> 00:24:12.833
meaning that if they wanna opt out of 16,
they can't say it's 12.

487
00:24:12.833 --> 00:24:16.881
That would be against EU law and
they would be not able to do that, but

488
00:24:16.881 --> 00:24:18.599
they can go down as low 13.

489
00:24:18.599 --> 00:24:23.040
But it has to be, unless they
create an exception, 16 or older.

490
00:24:23.040 --> 00:24:27.090
If it's below 16, with no exception,
then a parent must opt in a consent for

491
00:24:27.090 --> 00:24:31.550

00:24:31.550 --> 00:24:33.910
Which, again, is a a very very strong and

00:24:33.910 --> 00:24:37.610

00:24:39.720 --> 00:24:42.492

497
00:24:44.726 --> 00:24:45.652
>> Yes.

00:24:45.652 --> 00:24:49.891
>> I mean it is a huge, huge category that

00:24:49.891 --> 00:24:53.889

500
00:24:53.889 --> 00:24:56.726

00:24:57.490 --> 00:24:59.740
So that is encouraging,
very, very encouraging.

503
00:24:59.740 --> 00:25:00.500
>> Absolutely.

All right, again,
great information there, Adam.

00:25:02.780 --> 00:25:06.950

As we said, we're doing our overview,
we're gonna get back and

00:25:09.410 --> 00:25:11.800

00:25:11.800 --> 00:25:13.660
But we thank you for

00:25:13.660 --> 00:25:16.030

taken a lot of this for granted.

510
00:26:45.310 --> 00:26:49.517
But the reality is, may not be as simple
as it once was because we have personal

511
00:26:49.517 --> 00:26:54.073
data, of a general type, then we have
a category called sensitive personal data.

512
00:26:54.073 --> 00:26:58.799
The subcategory, sensitive personal data,
falls under special categories

513
00:26:58.799 --> 00:27:02.315
of personal data,
Article 9 in the GDPR calls these out.

514
00:27:02.315 --> 00:27:07.487
They're broadly defined, although there
are some updates and minor changes.

515
00:27:07.487 --> 00:27:12.530
The DPA, the Data Protection Act in
the UK defines these pretty clearly and

516
00:27:12.530 --> 00:27:16.705
the GDPR is aligned with just
about all of them in the same way.

517
00:27:16.705 --> 00:27:19.187
There's some minor updates and
variations, but in general.

518
00:27:19.187 --> 00:27:22.717
And I mentioned this, I think back in
episode one, genetic data and biometric

519
00:27:22.717 --> 00:27:27.107
data is now called in and brought in as
being a protected class and category of

520
00:27:27.107 --> 00:27:31.657
data, where it is processed in such a way
that uniquely identifies the individual.

521
00:27:31.657 --> 00:27:34.337
All companies that are doing
multifactoral authentication and

522
00:27:34.337 --> 00:27:38.117
using biometrics,
potentially have now a liability here.

523
00:27:38.117 --> 00:27:39.747
What about all those companies,
23 and Me, and

524
00:27:39.747 --> 00:27:43.350
all those other companies that
are doing all the genetic testing and

525
00:27:43.350 --> 00:27:46.530
trying to build the genetic
data bank around the world?

526
00:27:46.530 --> 00:27:51.030
This scares just the bejesus out of me,
I cannot even begin to describe

527
00:27:51.030 --> 00:27:53.470
to you how terrified I am
when I see these commercials.

528
00:27:53.470 --> 00:27:55.820
And people just seem to
think this is a good idea.

529
00:27:55.820 --> 00:27:59.660
>> Well, especially when you follow that
commercial up with an article about this

530
00:27:59.660 --> 00:28:04.560
organization that can now generate DNA,
or based on that,

531
00:28:04.560 --> 00:28:10.640
they can duplicate that stuff, and
give you a blood sample based on that.

532
00:28:10.640 --> 00:28:15.160
>> We live in fascinating times,
the Chinese curse that you

533
00:28:15.160 --> 00:28:19.140
should live in interesting times
revisits us on a regular basis.

534
00:28:19.140 --> 00:28:21.860
It's interesting because
we have these capabilities.

535
00:28:21.860 --> 00:28:25.230
Think about all the good that has come
from that kind of understanding of

536
00:28:25.230 --> 00:28:26.230
the human genome.

537
00:28:26.230 --> 00:28:29.730
Innovative treatments for all sorts of
diseases, people are living longer,

538
00:28:29.730 --> 00:28:32.130
we're saving people's lives,
that's all great stuff.

539
00:28:32.130 --> 00:28:36.340
When I say it scares the bejesus out of
me, not because that stuff scares me,

540
00:28:36.340 --> 00:28:38.960
that stuff is great,
we should do that, no doubt about it.

541
00:28:38.960 --> 00:28:41.490
But the problem you run
into with this stuff,

542
00:28:41.490 --> 00:28:43.740
from my perspective as
a security professional,

543
00:28:43.740 --> 00:28:48.460
as an IT focused individual who deals with
security and information security and

544
00:28:48.460 --> 00:28:54.740
the lack thereof in customers around
the world on a regular basis, and who has

545
00:28:54.740 --> 00:28:59.160
family members who are genetic counselors,
so I see this from multiple perspectives.

546
00:28:59.160 --> 00:29:02.960
And understanding exactly
what we can tell about you.

547
00:29:02.960 --> 00:29:06.960
And when you think about the fact that
you're essentially giving this information

548
00:29:06.960 --> 00:29:12.230
to an unknown third party, who has a great
job, has done a great job of marketing.

549
00:29:12.230 --> 00:29:17.190
But I'm waiting, I'm waiting and you've
heard it here first, replay this episode

550
00:29:17.190 --> 00:29:20.430
when this does happen, and I want you
to then get in touch with me, and

551
00:29:20.430 --> 00:29:23.660
tell me whether you believe that
what I told you is accurate.

552
00:29:23.660 --> 00:29:29.290
I am waiting for the announcement that
one of these companies got hacked.

553
00:29:29.290 --> 00:29:31.110
And that when they got hacked, and

554
00:29:31.110 --> 00:29:34.410
all this information was exposed,
what happens then?

555
00:29:34.410 --> 00:29:37.620
Because, I don't think
anybody really truly gets

556
00:29:37.620 --> 00:29:40.100
the potential liabilities
that are involved here.

557
00:29:40.100 --> 00:29:44.200
This is not okay, they got my bank account
information, they stole my money, and

558
00:29:44.200 --> 00:29:47.690
now insurance is gonna repay the bank and
I'm gonna get my money back.

559
00:29:47.690 --> 00:29:51.320
Yeah that all happens, that's
unfortunate for you, it's inconvenient,

560
00:29:51.320 --> 00:29:54.040
it's unfortunate for the bank,
it's inconvenient for them.

561
00:29:54.040 --> 00:29:55.900
The insurance company has
gotta reach into their pocket,

562
00:29:55.900 --> 00:29:58.970
Lord knows they have enough money,
so they should pay, so fine.

563
00:29:58.970 --> 00:30:02.580
All of that's absolutely horrible,
should not happen, it is illegal,

564
00:30:02.580 --> 00:30:04.340
it's wrong,
I don't disagree with any of that.

565
00:30:04.340 --> 00:30:04.870
But you know what?

566
00:30:04.870 --> 00:30:06.285
If you have end of the day,

567
00:30:06.285 --> 00:30:09.355
we're essentially talking about
a victimless crime, right?

568
00:30:09.355 --> 00:30:11.565
Because you're going to get
your money back, whether or

569
00:30:11.565 --> 00:30:14.125
not the bad person who did
this gets caught, fine.

570
00:30:14.125 --> 00:30:17.365
Yes, people are ultimately victims
because insurance rates go up and all

571
00:30:17.365 --> 00:30:21.415
that other stuff, but nobody was really
hurt in a meaningful way by that activity.

572
00:30:21.415 --> 00:30:26.015
Even though it was illegal and
it was wrong, but nobody really got hurt.

573
00:30:26.015 --> 00:30:30.350
This kind of stuff, we don't really
know what's in that Pandora's box.

574
00:30:30.350 --> 00:30:34.200
All we know is that somebody,
theoretically,

575
00:30:34.200 --> 00:30:37.882
has your genetic information,
essentially can make another you.

576
00:30:37.882 --> 00:30:39.940
>> That's what I was getting ready to say,
a second Adam over here.

577
00:30:39.940 --> 00:30:44.500
>> And we don't really know from
a perspective of what that means,

578
00:30:44.500 --> 00:30:46.580
what that information could be used to do.

579
00:30:46.580 --> 00:30:49.210
I'm not suggesting that means you're gonna
walk down the street and see yourself,

580
00:30:49.210 --> 00:30:51.470
right, that may happen in the future.

581
00:30:51.470 --> 00:30:55.125
And Lord knows that's always
a possibility, but I'm more concerned

582
00:30:55.125 --> 00:30:58.985
about the immediate, next five to
ten years when these breaches occur.

583
00:30:58.985 --> 00:31:01.075
Somebody takes that genetic data and

584
00:31:01.075 --> 00:31:03.855
figures out how to use
it to blackmail you.

585
00:31:03.855 --> 00:31:08.060
I'm gonna tell your employer that you are
potentially suffering from this disease.

586
00:31:08.060 --> 00:31:12.150
Or that you have the ability to
generate and develop this disease, and

587
00:31:12.150 --> 00:31:15.620
as a result I'm gonna go to your insurance
company and I'm gonna blackmail you.

588
00:31:15.620 --> 00:31:19.450
Or I'm gonna make it clear to
everybody in your life around you

589
00:31:19.450 --> 00:31:20.540
that you have this issue.

590
00:31:20.540 --> 00:31:24.400
I mean there's just unlimited chaos
that can derive from this, and yet

591
00:31:24.400 --> 00:31:30.010
I see people lining up, I mean,
it's like they're giving away free money.

592
00:31:30.010 --> 00:31:31.510
People think this is
the best thing in the world.

593
00:31:31.510 --> 00:31:32.980
I talked to people that have done this and

594
00:31:32.980 --> 00:31:36.420
I just don't get,
from their perspective, what is so

595
00:31:36.420 --> 00:31:41.460
important about knowing this information
that common sense goes out the window.

596
00:31:41.460 --> 00:31:43.710
I understand if you want to
know where you came from.

597
00:31:43.710 --> 00:31:47.600
I understand if you have a burning
desire to figure out genetically

598
00:31:47.600 --> 00:31:49.890
what parts of the world
you're coming from.

599
00:31:49.890 --> 00:31:52.220
I get that, not that there's
anything wrong with that, but

600
00:31:52.220 --> 00:31:53.500
do it in a secure way.

601
00:31:53.500 --> 00:31:56.940
Go to a genetic counselor,
do it as a one on one activity.

602
00:31:56.940 --> 00:32:00.250
Have it done in a way that will
then ensure your security,

603
00:32:00.250 --> 00:32:02.480
your privacy, your confidentiality.

604
00:32:02.480 --> 00:32:05.390
Don't give it to a nameless,
faceless company on the web.

605
00:32:05.390 --> 00:32:07.680
>> Put it in the mail.
>> That is gonna market that data and

606
00:32:07.680 --> 00:32:08.960
do Lord knows what with it.

607
00:32:08.960 --> 00:32:12.010
Yet, people feel this is
a perfectly acceptable behavior.

608
00:32:12.010 --> 00:32:16.430
I just I'm constantly amazed
at just the seeming lack of

609
00:32:16.430 --> 00:32:19.510
understanding with regards to
safeguards and confidentiality.

610
00:32:19.510 --> 00:32:24.040
Yet time and time again, I'm proven, when
I think I've reached the absolute limit

611
00:32:24.040 --> 00:32:26.960
where I say okay there is no way
anybody else could be that dumb,

612
00:32:26.960 --> 00:32:30.560
something else come up, and
it's actually even worse.

613
00:32:30.560 --> 00:32:32.940
And this has become a real issue
in the last several years.

614
00:32:32.940 --> 00:32:34.900
Again, remember you heard it
here first when it happens.

615
00:32:34.900 --> 00:32:37.420
And I'm not saying this because
I want this to happen, but

616
00:32:37.420 --> 00:32:38.970
I promise you it's only a matter of time.

617
00:32:38.970 --> 00:32:39.630
>> Yeah, I man that's [INAUDIBLE].

618
00:32:39.630 --> 00:32:43.210
>> One or more of those companies is gonna
get hacked, this data's gonna leak out

619
00:32:43.210 --> 00:32:46.130
somewhere, and there's gonna be
absolute chaos that results.

620
00:32:46.130 --> 00:32:46.780
>> That is a juicy target
just sitting there.

621
00:32:46.780 --> 00:32:48.010
>> Because of this.

622
00:32:48.010 --> 00:32:49.900
I mean, I'm surprised it
hasn't happened until now.

623
00:32:49.900 --> 00:32:51.350
Yeah, because they say, well,
we're storing the data,

624
00:32:51.350 --> 00:32:52.330
it's encrypted, everything else.

625
00:32:52.330 --> 00:32:55.150
I'm sure it is, but
encrypted data gets stolen all the time,

626
00:32:55.150 --> 00:32:58.250
it still winds up on the web, and people
find a way to understand what it is.

627
00:32:58.250 --> 00:33:01.400
So because you encrypt it doesn't
mean you're encrypting it strongly.

628
00:33:01.400 --> 00:33:04.860
And because you're encrypting it strongly
doesn't mean it's strong enough.

629
00:33:04.860 --> 00:33:06.330
And these are issues and

630
00:33:06.330 --> 00:33:09.140
concerns that security professionals
have to be involved in.

631
00:33:09.140 --> 00:33:12.900
And unfortunately, more often than not,
we find in these situations that

632
00:33:12.900 --> 00:33:16.750
companies don't employ those professionals
properly, early enough in the process

633
00:33:16.750 --> 00:33:20.540
to ensure success, and
they pay the price after the fact.

634
00:33:20.540 --> 00:33:24.700
I'm really hoping I'm wrong about this
one, but I have a sneaking suspicion and

635
00:33:24.700 --> 00:33:27.210
a burning suspicion that I'm
going to be proved to be right.

636
00:33:27.210 --> 00:33:28.510
It's only a matter of time.

637
00:33:28.510 --> 00:33:30.950
So anyways, as I was saying,
sensitive personal data.

638
00:33:30.950 --> 00:33:34.320
Articles 9 and
10 in the GDPR speak to this specifically.

639
00:33:34.320 --> 00:33:39.590
Things like biometric and biomarker data
of a variety of types is now included,

640
00:33:39.590 --> 00:33:42.250
and rightly so
is protected here under the GDPR.

641
00:33:42.250 --> 00:33:45.450
Hopefully this will extend out
to other areas over time, but

642
00:33:45.450 --> 00:33:47.280
sensitive personal data is a category.

643
00:33:47.280 --> 00:33:49.530
Very important for us to consider and
think about as well.

644
00:33:49.530 --> 00:33:51.830
>> All right, Adam, again,
great conversation, great stuff.

645
00:33:51.830 --> 00:33:54.150
As we take our overview look at the GDPR,

646
00:33:54.150 --> 00:33:57.150
the General Data Protection Regulation
of the EU.

647
00:33:57.150 --> 00:33:58.720
We appreciate your insight,

648
00:33:58.720 --> 00:34:01.220
we hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

649
00:34:01.220 --> 00:34:04.080
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

650
00:34:04.080 --> 00:34:05.200
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

651
00:34:05.200 --> 00:34:07.157
>> And we'll see you next time.

652
00:34:07.157 --> 00:34:13.145
[MUSIC]

653
00:34:13.145 --> 00:34:16.714
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:01.568
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.568 --> 00:00:06.592
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.592 --> 00:00:08.297
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.297 --> 00:00:12.370
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.370 --> 00:00:15.872
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:15.872 --> 00:00:17.603
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and

7
00:00:17.603 --> 00:00:21.252
today we are discussing the General
Data Protection Regulation in the EU.

8
00:00:21.252 --> 00:00:22.205
In this episode,

9
00:00:22.205 --> 00:00:26.346
we're gonna be taking a look at some of
the core principles found in the GDPR.

10
00:00:26.346 --> 00:00:28.650
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:28.650 --> 00:00:29.287
Welcome, Adam.

12
00:00:29.287 --> 00:00:30.457
>> Thank you very much,

13
00:00:30.457 --> 00:00:35.300
glad to be here talking about data
protection principles underneath the GDPR.

14
00:00:35.300 --> 00:00:38.210
The GDPR sets out data protection
principles to establish

15
00:00:38.210 --> 00:00:41.110
this framework we've been talking about
throughout our overview episodes.

16
00:00:41.110 --> 00:00:44.790
If you haven't seen those,
it wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing for

17
00:00:44.790 --> 00:00:45.720
you to go back to take a look.

18
00:00:45.720 --> 00:00:48.000
It's not really necessarily pertinent and

19
00:00:48.000 --> 00:00:50.960
specific to this part of
the conversation in this one episode.

20
00:00:50.960 --> 00:00:53.470
But more broadly,
it really does set the tone for

21
00:00:53.470 --> 00:00:56.890
all the additional episodes that are gonna
come, both now and after this one.

22
00:00:56.890 --> 00:01:00.310
But the data protection principle set
out the main responsibilities for

23
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:03.080
organizations under the GDPR
that we've been speaking to

24
00:01:03.080 --> 00:01:06.300
in many of our episodes under
the overview topic area.

25
00:01:06.300 --> 00:01:10.070
We've talked about several articles,
Articles 33 through 37 for

26
00:01:10.070 --> 00:01:12.220
instance, Articles 9 and 10.

27
00:01:12.220 --> 00:01:15.990
We're gonna do a little deeper dive
here on Article 5 of the GDPR.

28
00:01:15.990 --> 00:01:19.486
The requirements around how personal
data needs to be dealt with and

29
00:01:19.486 --> 00:01:21.520
needs to be monitored and maintained.

30
00:01:21.520 --> 00:01:23.990
We've spoken about that at length,
we'll continue to do that.

31
00:01:23.990 --> 00:01:30.510
But the interesting thing is that
the GDPR itself does not necessarily deal

32
00:01:30.510 --> 00:01:35.260
with these particular principles relating
to individual's rights in the body.

33
00:01:35.260 --> 00:01:39.130
They're dealt with as these articles and
additional areas in the legislation

34
00:01:39.130 --> 00:01:42.480
kind of the backend of the legislation
as I was talking about.

35
00:01:42.480 --> 00:01:44.770
You will see the developed
thought process here.

36
00:01:44.770 --> 00:01:48.572
But we have to look a little deeper and
dig down into some of these areas.

37
00:01:48.572 --> 00:01:50.580
Give me just one second,
while we're talking.

38
00:01:50.580 --> 00:01:53.210
I'm just gonna bring that up for
us so we can take a look.

39
00:01:53.210 --> 00:01:55.770
I've shown you this in
some of the other areas.

40
00:01:55.770 --> 00:01:59.720
I just have to get to the right article
that we want to take a look at.

41
00:01:59.720 --> 00:02:02.550
So just bear with me one
minute while we do that.

42
00:02:02.550 --> 00:02:06.350
But the idea here if you wanna join
me here, it can show you right now.

43
00:02:06.350 --> 00:02:10.010
So at the, roughly about 35 to 40 page

44
00:02:10.010 --> 00:02:14.630
mark in the document of 88 pages,
we see Chapter 1, General Provisions,

45
00:02:14.630 --> 00:02:18.170
Article 1, kinda starting and
deal with these articles being developed.

46
00:02:18.170 --> 00:02:22.680
And as we go down, Material scope and
Territorial scope,

47
00:02:22.680 --> 00:02:24.930
these are just the basics,
then we have definitions.

48
00:02:24.930 --> 00:02:29.153
Under the regulation, you'll water
the elements we're starting to talk about,

49
00:02:29.153 --> 00:02:32.952
personal data for instance,
processing, restriction of, profiling,

50
00:02:32.952 --> 00:02:35.504
pseudonominization, that
term you love to use.

51
00:02:35.504 --> 00:02:36.570
>> Yes.
>> And you can see the spelling,

52
00:02:36.570 --> 00:02:37.480
as I talked about there.

53
00:02:37.480 --> 00:02:41.740
All the terms in the regulation, a lot of
them we've defined in the General Overview

54
00:02:41.740 --> 00:02:47.430
episodes, are all here in this area under
Article Four, and then as we go down,

55
00:02:47.430 --> 00:02:50.450
this is essentially just the vocabulary
list, right, for the GDPR.

56
00:02:50.450 --> 00:02:51.880
Very important to take
a look at all of this,

57
00:02:51.880 --> 00:02:55.960
this supervisory authority, what it is,
all right, how it's made up.

58
00:02:55.960 --> 00:02:57.180
And then we get to article five,

59
00:02:57.180 --> 00:02:59.920
principles relating to
processing of personal data.

60
00:02:59.920 --> 00:03:04.340
When we talk about about principles, we're
gonna focus on Article 5 as one example,

61
00:03:04.340 --> 00:03:08.638
we're talking about the development of
these stock processes within the framework

62
00:03:08.638 --> 00:03:09.313
of the GDPR.

63
00:03:09.313 --> 00:03:13.406
But they're laid out here as you
could see in Chapter 2 in this case,

64
00:03:13.406 --> 00:03:17.289
in this principle lateral to
the actual legislation of the GDPR,

65
00:03:17.289 --> 00:03:19.420
or the actual body of the document.

66
00:03:19.420 --> 00:03:23.320
These are all supporting elements that
bring to life and add the capabilities and

67
00:03:23.320 --> 00:03:25.380
the deep protections
that we are looking at.

68
00:03:25.380 --> 00:03:29.430
So, the most significant one is
probably the accountability principle.

69
00:03:29.430 --> 00:03:32.600
The accountability principle
around the idea that we as

70
00:03:32.600 --> 00:03:36.240
either processors and/or controllers,

71
00:03:36.240 --> 00:03:40.200
essentially the business end that is
gathering the data from the data subjects.

72
00:03:40.200 --> 00:03:42.260
Monitoring it, managing it,
maintaining it.

73
00:03:42.260 --> 00:03:44.050
We have to comply with
these principles and

74
00:03:44.050 --> 00:03:48.650
show documented irrefutable
evidence of the fact, right?

75
00:03:48.650 --> 00:03:49.200
That we are doing.

76
00:03:49.200 --> 00:03:51.490
So, it's also very important for
us to be thinking about that.

77
00:03:51.490 --> 00:03:55.010
We have to document the decisions we
take under processing activities and

78
00:03:55.010 --> 00:03:59.540
validate them, and have them available
should we need to provide that proof.

00:03:38.030 --> 00:03:40.325
9, and

00:04:12.680 --> 00:04:15.202

00:04:18.482 --> 00:04:23.103

84
00:04:27.970 --> 00:04:31.487
So for instance,
if we decide that the lawful basis for

00:04:40.016 --> 00:04:44.332
really went through the logic of why

00:04:44.332 --> 00:04:47.050
is not under the definitions in the GDPR.

00:04:47.050 --> 00:04:51.210

going to come from the data subject,

90
00:04:51.210 --> 00:04:54.330
essentially the person who is
gonna be giving us the data.

91
00:04:54.330 --> 00:04:58.210

92
00:04:58.210 --> 00:05:02.010
They have to, essentially, through their
action, word, or deed, provide consent.

93
00:05:02.010 --> 00:05:04.946
It cannot be passive in almost every case.

94
00:05:04.946 --> 00:05:09.020
There is an exception for passive opt in,

95
00:05:09.020 --> 00:05:12.642
Primarily, things like
pre-filled in forms,

96
00:05:12.642 --> 00:05:16.716
where the user clicks OK, and
we accept that as opt in.

97
00:05:16.716 --> 00:05:20.116
Where which we may have done in the past,
and we often have talked about seeing and

98
00:05:20.116 --> 00:05:21.240
doing on the web.

99
00:05:21.240 --> 00:05:24.560
That's not an acceptable form
in most cases these days.

100
00:05:24.560 --> 00:05:28.668
We would need to instead of prepopulating
that form, have that form available but

101
00:05:28.668 --> 00:05:30.882
have have the user fill
the information in.

102
00:05:30.882 --> 00:05:34.339

00:05:34.339 --> 00:05:37.676
most likely at the bottom, or

104
00:05:37.676 --> 00:05:41.012
that says I acknowledge the terms
of service, or I acknowledge and

105
00:05:41.012 --> 00:05:44.197

laid out here and explained.

106
00:05:44.197 --> 00:05:46.060
Whatever the language would be.

107
00:05:46.060 --> 00:05:50.437
The user has to actively opt in by
doing that and then clicking OK or

108
00:05:50.437 --> 00:05:55.869
providing the submission for that data for
us to consider that to be acceptable.

109
00:05:55.869 --> 00:06:00.419
And so when we think about something
like relying on the user's consent, or

110
00:06:00.419 --> 00:06:03.548
the data subject's consent
to process their data,

111
00:06:03.548 --> 00:06:07.630
that's gonna give the user
stronger rights under the GDPR.

112
00:06:07.630 --> 00:06:10.460
Rights to complain if things
are not done a certain way.

113
00:06:10.460 --> 00:06:14.720
Rights to a speedy resolution of
requests to validate their data.

114
00:06:14.720 --> 00:06:16.050
A right to be forgotten and

115
00:06:16.050 --> 00:06:19.740
essentially to have their data removed,
under certain circumstances.

116
00:06:19.740 --> 00:06:24.852
So we have to think about that because if
as the processor and as the controller,

117
00:06:24.852 --> 00:06:30.590
we are relying on that right to consent
as our lawful right to process data.

118
00:06:30.590 --> 00:06:34.610
We now have bought into an additional
series of rights, accountability, and

119
00:06:34.610 --> 00:06:39.530
responsibilities, that as the provider and
the manager of that information,

120
00:06:39.530 --> 00:06:41.200
we actually, now are on the hook for.

121
00:06:41.200 --> 00:06:44.210
So we do need to be aware of that and
just want to think about that and

122
00:06:44.210 --> 00:06:45.230
understand that.

00:06:45.230 --> 00:06:47.313
To that end, if you wanna join me here,

00:06:55.916 --> 00:06:58.550

Remember I said there's 88

00:07:14.942 --> 00:07:16.755

133
00:07:16.755 --> 00:07:19.355

137
00:07:27.627 --> 00:07:31.782
We have to have at least one of
these particular items applying for

138
00:07:31.782 --> 00:07:33.328

139
00:07:33.328 --> 00:07:35.308
So we have options,

140
00:07:35.308 --> 00:07:39.631

142
00:07:43.831 --> 00:07:46.331

143
00:07:46.331 --> 00:07:47.989
The data subject has given consent,

00:07:47.989 --> 00:07:51.304
I mentioned this would be one example

145
00:07:51.304 --> 00:07:54.746
to the processing of their personal

00:07:54.746 --> 00:07:56.256

147
00:07:56.256 --> 00:08:00.228

00:08:00.228 --> 00:08:01.670

149
00:08:01.670 --> 00:08:03.050

150
00:08:03.050 --> 00:08:06.790

151
00:08:06.790 --> 00:08:09.500

00:08:09.500 --> 00:08:11.180

158
00:08:32.310 --> 00:08:35.570
There's all these things we could think
of where some sort of contract would

00:08:35.570 --> 00:08:36.760

00:08:36.760 --> 00:08:40.640

00:08:40.640 --> 00:08:44.207

00:08:44.207 --> 00:08:47.074

00:08:47.074 --> 00:08:51.176

00:08:54.483 --> 00:08:58.177

00:08:58.177 --> 00:09:02.047

We've actually spoken to

So when we think about this

28

Let's start, and by the way, no particular

30

But we have to list them in some order.

[LAUGH]

we will see them in the document, but I

not prioritizing them by saying number

34

So first one, the right to be informed.

35

We've talked about this concept and

36

The right to be inform and
to be inform then obligation,

37

Quoting.

[LAUGH]

In some episodes, I emphasize some of

44
00:02:07.601 --> 00:02:09.970

meaning we have to make sure.

45
00:02:11.130 --> 00:02:14.380
As we think about the right to be
informed, both as the controller and

46
00:02:14.380 --> 00:02:16.265
the processor side of the conversation.

47
00:02:16.265 --> 00:02:20.925
Who's doing the gathering, who's doing
the processing, who's overseeing that,

48
00:02:20.925 --> 00:02:24.525
what data are we getting, how are we
gonna manage it, lawfully processing.

49
00:02:24.525 --> 00:02:27.735
All things we've talked about,
that when we do that,

50
00:02:27.735 --> 00:02:31.920
remember that the data subject has a right
to be informed about the use of that data.

51
00:02:31.920 --> 00:02:35.057
the stipulated requirements around
gathering through consent, and

52
00:02:35.057 --> 00:02:36.928
all the things that we've talked about.

53
00:02:36.928 --> 00:02:40.168
Right number two,
the right of access under the GDPR,

54
00:02:40.168 --> 00:02:42.706
individuals do have as we've talked about

55
00:02:42.706 --> 00:02:47.447
the right to obtain information about
themselves, about their information.

56
00:02:47.447 --> 00:02:51.763
In other words, if I maintain data
on a data subject under the GTPR,

57
00:02:51.763 --> 00:02:56.537
that data subject has the right of access
to request from the controller and

58
00:02:56.537 --> 00:03:01.037
processor, information about

59
00:03:01.037 --> 00:03:05.075
And whether or not that information is
