60
00:03:05.075 --> 00:03:08.365
And remember, they have a right to claim
that they would like to have that removed.

61
00:03:08.365 --> 00:03:09.905
The right to be forgotten.

62
00:03:09.905 --> 00:03:11.869
And we have this data processing,

63
00:03:11.869 --> 00:03:15.335
thought processing capability
by lawful processing.

64
00:03:15.335 --> 00:03:18.665
But also protection, with the role
of the data protection officer.

65
00:03:18.665 --> 00:03:21.025
Which becomes the advocate,
in many respects,

66
00:03:21.025 --> 00:03:25.230
for the rights of the individual, for
the data subject and their rights.

67
00:03:25.230 --> 00:03:29.620
The data protection officer, as we laid
out in our conversation about that role.

68
00:03:29.620 --> 00:03:32.350
Is the point person on
behalf of the controller and

69
00:03:32.350 --> 00:03:35.140
processor function in the organization.

70
00:03:35.140 --> 00:03:39.160
They are the entity or the role that
would be dealing with data subjects,

71
00:03:39.160 --> 00:03:41.950
if there is concern or
need for them to communicate.

72
00:03:41.950 --> 00:03:45.780
They are the conduit between the
organization and the supervisory agency,

73
00:03:45.780 --> 00:03:48.560
that oversees and
handles complaints and concerns.

74
00:03:48.560 --> 00:03:53.430
So they become this middle ground so
to speak, and this advocate on both sides.

75
00:03:53.430 --> 00:03:56.679
That is gonna control and
process the flow of information.

76
00:03:56.679 --> 00:04:00.440
So right of access very important,
right to confirm that their data is being

77
00:04:00.440 --> 00:04:04.203
processed meaning the rights of the deaf
subject, rights to understand and

78
00:04:04.203 --> 00:04:06.880
access their personal
data on file to validate.

79
00:04:06.880 --> 00:04:09.890
And verify that it is legitimate
up-to-date and consistent.

80
00:04:09.890 --> 00:04:13.770
And other supplementary information,
really around things in the Privacy.

81
00:04:13.770 --> 00:04:17.530
Notice, meaning have the terms of
service in the terms of privacy

82
00:04:17.530 --> 00:04:20.320
been applied properly if
they have been updated, or

83
00:04:20.320 --> 00:04:23.920
need of updating are we aware of that,
we see this for

84
00:04:23.920 --> 00:04:28.960
instance in the United States and in many
other countries as well when, as of late.

85
00:04:28.960 --> 00:04:31.500
When I say as of late, I mean,
in the last several years.

86
00:04:31.500 --> 00:04:36.130
Again, anticipating the rolling
effect of the implementation of

87
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:39.950
GDPR over the last couple of years,
since we've been ramping up.

88
00:04:39.950 --> 00:04:43.818
You see things like, we talked
about the now new notifications on

89
00:04:43.818 --> 00:04:47.139
websites about the use of
terms of privacy and cookies.

90
00:04:47.139 --> 00:04:49.801
We see those bars you and I have
talked about them in prior episodes.

91
00:04:49.801 --> 00:04:54.537
And we saw them emerging in European
centric and European based businesses

92
00:04:54.537 --> 00:04:59.585
initially, and that has kind of rolled
back into many other areas of the world.

93
00:04:59.585 --> 00:05:03.997
And many companies regardless of
geography are using that now as a model,

94
00:05:03.997 --> 00:05:06.701
because we know that that
does meet the bar for

95
00:05:06.701 --> 00:05:11.199
satisfaction and verification under
the GDPR, so we see that happening.

96
00:05:11.199 --> 00:05:14.675
But also when you see credit card
companies and vendors update their terms

97
00:05:14.675 --> 00:05:18.770
of service, especially banks and credit
card companies cuz they tend to do this.

98
00:05:18.770 --> 00:05:22.350
Where they will send you maybe two to
three times per year depending on kind of

99
00:05:22.350 --> 00:05:26.760
their cycle, they'll send you the updated
terms of service in writing, so

100
00:05:26.760 --> 00:05:27.880
that you have a copy of them.

101
00:05:27.880 --> 00:05:29.770
Not just post them online and
point you to them and

102
00:05:29.770 --> 00:05:34.060
say, by the way, read through ten page
of stuff, there's been an update.

103
00:05:34.060 --> 00:05:37.740
But in the United States in particular,
because of changes in the last several

104
00:05:37.740 --> 00:05:41.460
years to the rights of the consumer,
under the Obama administration.

105
00:05:41.460 --> 00:05:44.580
As that whole thought
process went forward and

106
00:05:44.580 --> 00:05:48.742
was ultimately passed into law,
at least as of now, anyway.

107
00:05:48.742 --> 00:05:51.534
We're waiting to see whether or not,
[LAUGH] that will be modified under

108
00:05:51.534 --> 00:05:54.247
the current administration,
what changes may be made ultimately.

109
00:05:54.247 --> 00:05:58.159
But currently anyway, banks have
a responsibility to notify you and

110
00:05:58.159 --> 00:06:01.802
update you, when the terms of
service around your credit card or

111
00:06:01.802 --> 00:06:06.186
your bank usage changes, and the right
to understand the rights of privacy,

112
00:06:06.186 --> 00:06:08.490
and the rights of service overall.

113
00:06:08.490 --> 00:06:09.170
Are enshrined there.

114
00:06:09.170 --> 00:06:12.960
So we do see a lot of this playing
out in different geographies and

115
00:06:12.960 --> 00:06:14.430
different jurisdictions.

116
00:06:14.430 --> 00:06:19.300
But because of various and competitive
needs, we see generic behavior.

117
00:06:19.300 --> 00:06:21.115
It may not be specific in every entity.

118
00:06:21.115 --> 00:06:22.805
But in general,
we can lump them together and

119
00:06:22.805 --> 00:06:27.585
say these kinds of behaviors speak to this
kind of a right, so just be aware of that.

120
00:06:27.585 --> 00:06:29.365
So right number two, the right of access.

121
00:06:29.365 --> 00:06:30.995
Right number one,
the right to be informed.

122
00:06:30.995 --> 00:06:33.885
Right number three,
the right to rectification.

123
00:06:33.885 --> 00:06:37.727
The right to rectification is the right to
understand that if our data is inaccurate

124
00:06:37.727 --> 00:06:41.817
for some reason, we have the right to
point that out, to then seek redress and

125
00:06:41.817 --> 00:06:45.967
have that, assuming we can validate
that legitimately, have that updated.

126
00:06:45.967 --> 00:06:49.118
And we have the right to have that
done in a timely fashion, right?

127
00:06:49.118 --> 00:06:52.257
So, we can think of this as integrity,
if you wanna think about it around data.

128
00:06:52.257 --> 00:06:53.821
We've talked about it that way before.

129
00:06:53.821 --> 00:06:57.809
Individuals are entitled to have personal
data rectified, if it is inaccurate or

130
00:06:57.809 --> 00:06:59.788
incomplete is what the GDPR says.

131
00:06:59.788 --> 00:07:02.478
If we have disclosed the personal
data in question to third parties,

132
00:07:02.478 --> 00:07:06.988
meaning you as the controller-processor
have disclosed that to third parties,

133
00:07:06.988 --> 00:07:10.640
then we, the controller-processor
function, have a right and

134
00:07:10.640 --> 00:07:16.180
a responsibility to go and update that,
is the downstream discussion that we had.

135
00:07:16.180 --> 00:07:19.840
We have to inform them of
the rectification where possible.

136
00:07:19.840 --> 00:07:23.229
we also have to inform individuals about
the third party's to whom data has been

137
00:07:23.229 --> 00:07:25.599
disclosed where appropriator's
part of this right.

138
00:07:25.599 --> 00:07:29.830
So for instance, if we,
let's just say hypothetically,

139
00:07:29.830 --> 00:07:34.600
as the controller processor entity,
perhaps our Megacorp A.

140
00:07:34.600 --> 00:07:38.840
We'll call ourselves Megacorp A, Megabank
A, whatever you wanna call yourself.

141
00:07:38.840 --> 00:07:43.410
And if we are the global entity of this
conglomerate set of financial service

142
00:07:43.410 --> 00:07:47.830
businesses, and we own that data,
and we then find out

143
00:07:47.830 --> 00:07:51.970
because we have shared it downstream with
third parties, other lines of business.

144
00:07:51.970 --> 00:07:56.102
That are underneath our umbrella and
perhaps partner with our organizations.

145
00:07:56.102 --> 00:07:59.702
And then we found out through a submission
from the user that the right to

146
00:07:59.702 --> 00:08:02.430
rectification has been
called in question and.

147
00:08:02.430 --> 00:08:03.860
There's an update to
the status of that data.

148
00:08:03.860 --> 00:08:08.038
We would have to push those updates down
to those other lines of business and

149
00:08:08.038 --> 00:08:12.150
best effort, attempt to update them
because we have that responsibility

150
00:08:12.150 --> 00:08:13.830
declared under this right.

151
00:08:13.830 --> 00:08:16.520
So wanna make sure we're aware of that and
we think about that.

152
00:08:16.520 --> 00:08:20.560
Because it's not enough just to say hey,
I updated into the main database, but

153
00:08:20.560 --> 00:08:24.240
all those other places, I know nothing
about, I'm not on the hook for.

154
00:08:24.240 --> 00:08:25.840
Quite the opposite, GDPR says,

155
00:08:25.840 --> 00:08:29.080
by the way, you need to make sure you pay
attention that you are updating that.

156
00:08:29.080 --> 00:08:32.460
>> Which kind of falls in line with
the next clause that we look at,

157
00:08:32.460 --> 00:08:34.580
for the erasure portion as well.

158
00:08:34.580 --> 00:08:37.700
You should also,
coming from an IT perspective,

159
00:08:37.700 --> 00:08:40.950
you know maybe I had a catastrophic
situation on a particular server,

160
00:08:40.950 --> 00:08:43.390
there was some kind of
fail over implementation.

161
00:08:43.390 --> 00:08:47.220
And you need to think about these things,
like hey, I might erase or change

162
00:08:47.220 --> 00:08:51.460
something in one particular location, but
if I ever have to pull those backups in or

163
00:08:51.460 --> 00:08:54.830
whatever, you have to
maintain those as well.

164
00:08:54.830 --> 00:08:55.670
>> Not exactly,

165
00:08:55.670 --> 00:08:58.770
the right to erasure is more commonly
called the right to be forgotten.

166
00:08:58.770 --> 00:09:00.250
>> Okay.
>> To the right to be forgotten,

167
00:09:00.250 --> 00:09:04.570
the idea that we can claim as an
individual that we would like our data to

168
00:09:04.570 --> 00:09:08.700
be removed and
no longer be referenced in the data set.

169
00:09:08.700 --> 00:09:11.540
And that the exact opposite
of what you're implying.

170
00:09:11.540 --> 00:09:15.870
That as a result the controller
processor has the responsibility now,

171
00:09:15.870 --> 00:09:19.860
to go through and remove our data from
any and all places where it may reside.

172
00:09:19.860 --> 00:09:25.020
And to certify to us that that data
request for removal has been carried out.

173
00:09:25.020 --> 00:09:26.170
>> For sure, that's what I'm saying.

174
00:09:26.170 --> 00:09:29.440
If I wanted to be removed from a do
not call list or something and

175
00:09:29.440 --> 00:09:33.320
then they pulled a backup with
my information still in and

176
00:09:33.320 --> 00:09:36.310
I get a call next week,
I'm not going to be too happy about that.

177
00:09:36.310 --> 00:09:39.660
>> Right, my point is they would have to,
they being the controlled processor.

178
00:09:39.660 --> 00:09:43.912
Would have to, under the GDPR, figure
out a way to ensure that if they had

179
00:09:43.912 --> 00:09:48.375
to restore a system to a certain point
in time, that the rights that have been

180
00:09:48.375 --> 00:09:53.168
carried out with regards to erasure are
overlapped as part of that restoration.

181
00:09:53.168 --> 00:09:55.040
So that they don't do what
you were describing, right?

182
00:09:55.040 --> 00:09:58.677
In other words, they don't say hey

you actually, her name has capital A,

[LAUGH]

So not the first name.

00:04:39.335 --> 00:04:41.265
All right, so, but

00:04:41.265 --> 00:04:42.774
>> I know, I was going to say,

00:04:42.774 --> 00:04:44.185
[LAUGH]
>> I would expect unusual,

00:04:44.185 --> 00:04:45.215
that's why I was wondering.

00:04:45.215 --> 00:04:46.385
So, the right to rectification,

110
00:04:46.385 --> 00:04:49.080
if you're joining back on the screen

111
00:04:49.080 --> 00:04:51.910
That was a random aside for

112
00:04:51.910 --> 00:04:54.420
In case you haven't seen us do that

113
00:04:54.420 --> 00:04:55.302
>> I know.
>> Because normally we have ones

00:04:55.302 --> 00:04:55.880
that are more involved.

115
00:04:55.880 --> 00:04:57.550
>> Have longer tangents, yeah.

116
00:04:57.550 --> 00:04:58.107
>> But it's an episodelet,

00:04:58.107 --> 00:04:59.440
so we have to keep it small
because everything is shorter.

118
00:04:59.440 --> 00:05:01.510
>> Shorter tangents, okay.

119
00:05:01.510 --> 00:05:05.205
>> All right, so, taking into account the
purposes for processing the data subject.

120
00:05:05.205 --> 00:05:09.750
Shall have the right to have this
incomplete personal data completed,

121
00:05:09.750 --> 00:05:11.990
including by means of providing
a supplementary state,

122
00:05:11.990 --> 00:05:14.850
which means we have options
to have this fixed.

123
00:05:14.850 --> 00:05:19.380
We may simply attach to the record
additional information that updates it.

124
00:05:19.380 --> 00:05:23.630
We may say to the processor or
the controller, hey, I need this fixed.

125
00:05:23.630 --> 00:05:25.660
They may say, okay, great, we'll redo it.

126
00:05:25.660 --> 00:05:28.960
Or they may say, just send in this
form and we'll update the record, so

127
00:05:28.960 --> 00:05:29.650
they have options.

128
00:05:29.650 --> 00:05:30.600
So do we.

129
00:05:30.600 --> 00:05:32.750
We need to understand that and
be aware of that.

130
00:05:32.750 --> 00:05:36.640
Now, I've mention Article 19,
so lets just scroll down here.

131
00:05:36.640 --> 00:05:39.940
Closing your eyes, pretending for a minute
that you're not seeing Article 17 and

132
00:05:39.940 --> 00:05:43.180
Article 18 cause we'll be coming back and
talking about those.

133
00:05:43.180 --> 00:05:48.120
But Article 19, notification obligation
regarding, [COUGH] excuse me, regarding

134
00:05:48.120 --> 00:05:52.430
rectification or erasure of personal data,
or restriction of processing.

135
00:05:52.430 --> 00:05:55.330
So, it says controller shall
communicate any rectification or

136
00:05:55.330 --> 00:06:00.100
erasure of personal data or restriction of
processing carried out in accordance with

137
00:06:00.100 --> 00:06:02.330
Article 16, 17 and 18 as well,
which bear on this also.

138
00:06:02.330 --> 00:06:05.660
To each recipient to whom
the personal data has been disclosed.

139
00:06:05.660 --> 00:06:09.670
>> Unless this proves impossible or
involves disproportionate effort.

140
00:06:09.670 --> 00:06:13.574
The controller shall inform the data
subject about those recipients of the data

141
00:06:13.574 --> 00:06:14.760
subject requested.

142
00:06:14.760 --> 00:06:19.710
Meaning that, again if we have third
parties downstream exposure for

143
00:06:19.710 --> 00:06:21.720
this data, we have to notify them,

144
00:06:21.720 --> 00:06:24.940
cascading this change down to
do our best to update everybody.

145
00:06:24.940 --> 00:06:26.780
We talked about this in a prior episode.

146
00:06:26.780 --> 00:06:29.910
And if the data subject wants
to know who those parties are,

147
00:06:29.910 --> 00:06:31.350
they have the right to request that.

148
00:06:31.350 --> 00:06:34.140
And the data then should
be provided to them.

149
00:06:34.140 --> 00:06:36.500
So the controller should then
be able to provide that.

150
00:06:36.500 --> 00:06:39.240
Now, if we're not gonna take action,
as the controller or

151
00:06:39.240 --> 00:06:43.940
processor, in response to this request,
we have to be aware that we may not.

152
00:06:43.940 --> 00:06:47.610
We must explain, as we said, to the data
subject why we're not going to.

153
00:06:47.610 --> 00:06:49.900
Remember, not every
request has to be honored.

154
00:06:49.900 --> 00:06:54.440
Not every request is gonna fall
under the category of doable and

155
00:06:54.440 --> 00:06:57.150
not excessive or not manifestly unfounded.

156
00:06:57.150 --> 00:06:59.730
And as a result we may or
may not choose to honor that request for

157
00:06:59.730 --> 00:07:00.940
a variety of reasons.

158
00:07:00.940 --> 00:07:04.030
If we choose to opt out,
we must explain why to the individual,

159
00:07:04.030 --> 00:07:06.170
to the data subject,
that we are not doing it.

160
00:07:06.170 --> 00:07:09.800
And inform them, if you remember,
of their right to go appeal that

161
00:07:09.800 --> 00:07:13.440
with a supervisory authority and
to seek a judicial remedy.

162
00:07:13.440 --> 00:07:17.390
That doesn't mean they'll get one, doesn't
mean they won't, doesn't mean that we will

163
00:07:17.390 --> 00:07:20.450
not then be compelled to respond
even though we chose not to.

164
00:07:20.450 --> 00:07:24.530
It simply means that there are options at
that point, forks in the road if you will,

165
00:07:24.530 --> 00:07:27.740
and we have to make everybody
aware of what their choices are.

166
00:07:27.740 --> 00:07:31.850
And then sit back and leave it at that
point in the hands of the data subject

167
00:07:31.850 --> 00:07:33.097
to decide on the next steps, right?

168
00:07:33.097 --> 00:07:35.490
Because then,
essentially the next move is up to them.

169
00:07:35.490 --> 00:07:38.680
If they choose not to appeal,
then that's where we stop.

170
00:07:38.680 --> 00:07:41.190
We've said no, they've not appealed that.

171
00:07:41.190 --> 00:07:44.720
And that's it, they can come back and
request again, we can keep saying no.

172
00:07:44.720 --> 00:07:47.260
But unless they go to
the supervisory authority and

173
00:07:47.260 --> 00:07:50.460
seek a judicial remedy,
that's not gonna change most likely.

174
00:07:50.460 --> 00:07:52.850
But if they do, and
the supervisory authority says,

175
00:07:52.850 --> 00:07:56.440
no you have to comply within
a reasonable amount of time.

176
00:07:56.440 --> 00:08:00.230
Perhaps giving us that two month extension
like we discussed maybe we need.

177
00:08:00.230 --> 00:08:01.570
Then that may change.

178
00:08:01.570 --> 00:08:05.710
So it's up to us to think about that both
from the controller-processor side, but

179
00:08:05.710 --> 00:08:07.222
also from the data-subject side.

180
00:08:07.222 --> 00:08:10.440
So, wanna just have that mind as we
talk about the right to rectify.

181
00:08:10.440 --> 00:08:11.910
All right well thank you for that tidbit.

182
00:08:11.910 --> 00:08:14.900
Do you have any final thoughts
before we move on to our next right?

183
00:08:14.900 --> 00:08:18.073
>> I do not other than to say that our
next right is gonna be the right to

184
00:08:18.073 --> 00:08:18.730
erasure.

185
00:08:18.730 --> 00:08:21.530
I'm taking a quick peek at
my list of rights here, so

186
00:08:21.530 --> 00:08:23.060
I can see which one comes up next.

187
00:08:23.060 --> 00:08:26.760
Keep up in track and on order,
given the way we did them in the overview.

188
00:08:26.760 --> 00:08:30.120
But the right to erasure as we talked
about, we're going to speak about next.

189
00:08:30.120 --> 00:08:32.610
But no, other than that, just to
remind everybody about the right and

190
00:08:32.610 --> 00:08:33.680
what we're going to be doing.

191
00:08:33.680 --> 00:08:36.590
I think we're good, keeping in mind that
you actually got a sneak peak at the right

192
00:08:36.590 --> 00:08:38.090
to erasure, right to be forgotten.

193
00:08:38.090 --> 00:08:40.960
That was Article 17, but we're going
to pretend I didn't tell you that.

194
00:08:40.960 --> 00:08:43.690
And when you come back, you're gonna
act surprised when I show it to you and

195
00:08:43.690 --> 00:08:44.615
explain why it's there.

196
00:08:44.615 --> 00:08:46.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> That was not the right

197
00:08:46.120 --> 00:08:47.385
that you were looking for.

198
00:08:47.385 --> 00:08:49.670
>> [LAUGH] All right, thank you Adam.

199
00:08:49.670 --> 00:08:54.220
And thank you joining us but stay tuned,
you don't wanna miss the right of erasure.

200
00:08:54.220 --> 00:08:57.265
Or the the right to be forgotten, okay.

201
00:08:57.265 --> 00:08:59.992
>> Don't forget the right to be forgotten.

202
00:08:59.992 --> 00:09:05.731
>> [LAUGH] Thank you, see you, bye.

203
00:09:05.731 --> 00:09:11.470
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

33
00:01:33.210 --> 00:01:37.840
So if you read carefully the statement

34
00:01:37.840 --> 00:01:42.120

shall have the right to obtain from

35
00:01:42.120 --> 00:01:46.720

36
00:01:46.720 --> 00:01:48.260

37
00:01:48.260 --> 00:01:51.240

the obligation to erase personal data

38
00:01:51.240 --> 00:01:52.150

39
00:01:52.150 --> 00:01:55.550

40

00:01:57.110 --> 00:02:00.150

43
00:02:03.420 --> 00:02:06.660
Meaning, you just make the request as

44
00:02:06.660 --> 00:02:07.860
And that's not the case.

45
00:02:07.860 --> 00:02:10.660
There are many exceptions
where you do not need, or

46
00:02:10.660 --> 00:02:12.750

47
00:02:12.750 --> 00:02:16.100
But there are many exceptions or
situations where you should, and

48
00:02:16.100 --> 00:02:19.060
legitimately do,
have the right to have your data erased.

49
00:02:19.060 --> 00:02:20.035
So we need to understand that.

50
00:02:20.035 --> 00:02:21.138
So we're gonna go take a look.

51
00:02:21.138 --> 00:02:25.057
So they need to respond, the controller
needs to respond in a timely fashion

52
00:02:25.057 --> 00:02:28.870

more of the following grounds apply.

53
00:02:28.870 --> 00:02:30.880
So let's just take a look here and
let me just scroll down.

54
00:02:32.390 --> 00:02:33.530
We have a listing of them.

55
00:02:33.530 --> 00:02:35.260
There's a total of six items here.

56
00:02:35.260 --> 00:02:38.260
You could see almost all of them,
kind of the bottom one poking out at

00:02:38.260 --> 00:02:40.020
the bottom there,

58
00:02:40.020 --> 00:02:41.490
So starting with item number 8.

59
00:02:41.490 --> 00:02:45.055

60
00:02:45.055 --> 00:02:47.860

61
00:02:47.860 --> 00:02:51.670

based on the terms of service and

62
00:02:51.670 --> 00:02:52.850
the terms of collection.

63
00:02:52.850 --> 00:02:56.300
And we are requesting to have it removed,
because it is just no longer valid.

64
00:02:56.300 --> 00:02:59.372
So that is a legitimate and
compelling reason to have that done.

65
00:02:59.372 --> 00:03:06.398
Item B, the data subject withdraws consent
on which the processing has been based.

66
00:03:06.398 --> 00:03:08.864
Meaning, I come back to you and say,
hey, guess what, you know what?

67
00:03:08.864 --> 00:03:11.118
I rethought this.

68
00:03:11.118 --> 00:03:15.425
I'm no longer interested in having
my opt-in, my consent be there.

69
00:03:15.425 --> 00:03:19.480
Please remove me as a result me deciding
to say no instead of saying yes, right?

70
00:03:19.480 --> 00:03:21.751
Buyer's remorse is what we
often refer to this as.

71
00:03:21.751 --> 00:03:23.800
>> All the time.
>> So we can think about that.

72
00:03:23.800 --> 00:03:26.710
And so,
if we base this on a point in Article 6 or

73
00:03:26.710 --> 00:03:31.320
Article 9, as you can see,
we are then able to do that.

74
00:03:31.320 --> 00:03:35.640
Item C, the data subject objects to
the processing pursuant to Article 21,

75
00:03:35.640 --> 00:03:36.400
which is down below.

76
00:03:36.400 --> 00:03:39.520
We haven't seen that yet, but
we can take a look quickly and we will.

77
00:03:39.520 --> 00:03:42.900
And there are no overriding
legitimate grounds for processing.

78
00:03:42.900 --> 00:03:44.890
Or the data subject objects

79
00:03:47.250 --> 00:03:51.280
to the processing pursuant to Article 21,
either subclause (1) or (2).

80
00:03:51.280 --> 00:03:53.358
Let's take a look at Article 21 for
just a moment.

81
00:03:53.358 --> 00:03:56.502
We'll come back up here in just a second.

82
00:03:56.502 --> 00:03:58.830
I'll just get rid of this real quick,
so we could see where we are.

83
00:03:58.830 --> 00:04:03.160
All right, so let's go down to Article 21.

84
00:04:03.160 --> 00:04:06.300
And Article 21, right here,
Right to Object, right?

85
00:04:06.300 --> 00:04:07.960
So obviously important to reference this.

86
00:04:07.960 --> 00:04:09.810
And again,
one of the rights we'll come back to and

87
00:04:09.810 --> 00:04:12.310
take a look at here in
a subsequent episode.

88
00:04:12.310 --> 00:04:14.045
But our episode-lette, right?

89
00:04:14.045 --> 00:04:17.815
But items 1 and 2, the data subject
shall have the right to object,

90
00:04:17.815 --> 00:04:20.935
on grounds relating to his or
her particular situation,

91
00:04:20.935 --> 00:04:24.315
at any time to processing
the personal data concerning them,

92
00:04:24.315 --> 00:04:27.249
which is based on points (e) or
(f) of Article 6.

93
00:04:27.249 --> 00:04:29.627
So meaning, you're going back and
forth doing these crazy things.

94
00:04:29.627 --> 00:04:31.557
Can you imagine the mind map that
actually [INAUDIBLE] all this?

95
00:04:31.557 --> 00:04:33.872
>> My goodness.
[LAUGH]

96
00:04:33.872 --> 00:04:34.867
>> Get a headache just trying to

97
00:04:34.867 --> 00:04:36.115
keep track of everything.

98
00:04:36.115 --> 00:04:39.945

And whether or not as a result of the
child understood fully the risks involved

324
00:15:56.009 --> 00:15:57.515
with consenting, right?

325
00:15:57.515 --> 00:16:02.510
Because a 14-year-old child may not be
able to say yes to the risks associated

326
00:16:02.510 --> 00:16:06.030
with using, and again,
not maligning any company.

327
00:16:06.030 --> 00:16:09.293
Not saying in any way, good or bad,
that this or that company does or

328
00:16:09.293 --> 00:16:12.123
doesn't do a good job with this,
we'll keep it generic.

329
00:16:12.123 --> 00:16:18.239
That using Company X's web service,
right, is a good or a bad idea.

330
00:16:18.239 --> 00:16:21.315
A 14-year-old opting in to get onto one
of these web services may not truly

331
00:16:21.315 --> 00:16:23.587
understand the risks involved
with creating a profile,

332
00:16:23.587 --> 00:16:25.919
perhaps sharing information
about themselves, right?

333
00:16:25.919 --> 00:16:29.258
>> Right, especially if it's more,
I don't wanna say peer pressure,

334
00:16:29.258 --> 00:16:32.667
but if it's more of the trendy thing
to do and other people are doing it.

335
00:16:32.667 --> 00:16:33.515
>> There could be an issue.

336
00:16:33.515 --> 00:16:35.409
>> Or just not educated to
those risks associated.

337
00:16:35.409 --> 00:16:39.377
>> Absolutely, so we have to understand
that as the controller or processor,

338
00:16:39.377 --> 00:16:43.283
we have to take extra special care here
where we deal with right of erasure or

339
00:16:43.283 --> 00:16:46.636
right to be forgotten around this
protected class of children.

340
00:16:46.636 --> 00:16:49.261
Because they may have opted in
without truly understanding the risks

341
00:16:49.261 --> 00:16:50.175
associated with this.

342
00:16:50.175 --> 00:16:53.515
And we have to give them,
essentially, what the GDRP is saying,

343
00:16:53.515 --> 00:16:57.646
the benefit of that doubt and be sensitive
to that fact that we probably have to act

344
00:16:57.646 --> 00:17:01.153
error on the side of caution there,
right, is what we're saying.

345
00:17:01.153 --> 00:17:05.090
And give them extra consideration for
lack of better way of putting that.

346
00:17:05.090 --> 00:17:06.530
We just have to understand that.

347
00:17:06.530 --> 00:17:09.870
So we do have to keep that in mind, and
also keep in mind obviously the timeline

348
00:17:09.870 --> 00:17:12.650
associated with responding
to these particular events.

349
00:17:12.650 --> 00:17:17.320
Do we have to tell other organizations
about the erasure of personal data?

350
00:17:17.320 --> 00:17:21.000
We did say that there is a requirement to
pay attention to downstream reporting.

351
00:17:21.000 --> 00:17:23.750
We called that out and
talked about that in the statute.

352
00:17:23.750 --> 00:17:26.780
So you just wanna keep in mind that these
things are all part of the right of

353
00:17:26.780 --> 00:17:30.300
erasure, right to be forgotten, as we've
been talking through in many respects.

354
00:17:30.300 --> 00:17:31.580
And we do have this ability and

355
00:17:31.580 --> 00:17:36.240
this need to inform the entire information
management chain of the desire to do this,

356
00:17:36.240 --> 00:17:39.970
because those downstream parties
have to also remove that data.

357
00:17:39.970 --> 00:17:43.100
Otherwise, it's gonna stay in
the public domain or wherever it is.

358
00:17:43.100 --> 00:17:47.149
And that will potentially not fully
satisfy the request from the data subject

359
00:17:47.149 --> 00:17:50.087
to remove that data,
which would then cause a problem.

360
00:17:50.087 --> 00:17:55.960
>> All right, so do you have any final
thoughts here for our right to erasure?

361
00:17:55.960 --> 00:17:57.368
>> I could say that I'll
be back with another-

362
00:17:57.368 --> 00:18:00.311
>> I was going to say I'll be back,

363
00:18:00.311 --> 00:18:01.286
[LAUGH]
>> With another

364
00:18:01.286 --> 00:18:01.831
right, but-
>> But

365
00:18:01.831 --> 00:18:02.646
you have to say it like, I'll be back.

366
00:18:02.646 --> 00:18:04.114
[LAUGH]
>> No, I'm not gonna say it like that.

367
00:18:04.114 --> 00:18:05.390
I'll leave that one to you.

368
00:18:05.390 --> 00:18:06.630
But I will say,

369
00:18:06.630 --> 00:18:09.590
that we are gonna come back continuing
our discussion with rights.

370
00:18:09.590 --> 00:18:12.310
This one will be the right
to restrict processing,

371
00:18:12.310 --> 00:18:15.230
which is actually Article 18 right
below where we were in the document.

372
00:18:15.230 --> 00:18:17.050
We're gonna continue
walking through there.

373
00:18:17.050 --> 00:18:19.669
But if you join us for
the next episode or episode-lette,

374
00:18:19.669 --> 00:18:22.619
we will be talking about the right
to restriction of processing.

375
00:18:22.619 --> 00:18:23.548
>> All right, thank you, Adam.

376
00:18:23.548 --> 00:18:25.166
And thank you for joining us as well.

377
00:18:25.166 --> 00:18:29.896
We'll see you next time here at ITProTV.

378
00:18:29.896 --> 00:18:35.877
[MUSIC]

379
00:18:35.877 --> 00:18:38.672
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.title: The Right to Restrict Processing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.924
Welcome to IT Pro TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:03.924 --> 00:00:07.914
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.914 --> 00:00:11.219
You're watching ITPRO TV.

4
00:00:11.219 --> 00:00:13.732
>> Welcome to your GDPR Series.

5
00:00:13.732 --> 00:00:16.310
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.310 --> 00:00:20.360
In this episode, we'll be taking a look
at the right to restrict processing.

7
00:00:20.360 --> 00:00:23.420
And back with us in the studios
today we have Mr. Adam Gordon.

8
00:00:23.420 --> 00:00:24.790
Thank you for joining us, Adam.

9
00:00:24.790 --> 00:00:26.110
>> Hello, everybody.

10
00:00:26.110 --> 00:00:30.070
I am hopefully in the next couple of
minutes in our little episode-lette here

11
00:00:30.070 --> 00:00:32.660
gonna help you walk through
the thought process around right to

12
00:00:32.660 --> 00:00:33.790
restriction to processing.

13
00:00:33.790 --> 00:00:36.470
Now, we've been talking a lot about
the different rights and the articles and

14
00:00:36.470 --> 00:00:37.540
we've kind of been going in order.

15
00:00:37.540 --> 00:00:40.400
You could see as we walked
through the articles, article 17,

16
00:00:40.400 --> 00:00:44.330
the right to erasure, article 18,
right to restriction and processing, etc.

17
00:00:44.330 --> 00:00:47.580
That we're using the document to our
advantage, really dissecting those

18
00:00:47.580 --> 00:00:50.960
sections that pertain to
the individual discussion on rights.

19
00:00:50.960 --> 00:00:52.690
We're gonna continue that
thought process here.

20
00:00:52.690 --> 00:00:55.890
Join me if you will,
the right to restriction of processing.

21
00:00:55.890 --> 00:01:00.027
So what we're talking about here is the
data subject's ability to go to the data

22
00:01:00.027 --> 00:01:03.606
controller or processor function and
say hey, i need you to stop what

23
00:01:03.606 --> 00:01:07.334
you're doing because something is
not right and here's why, right?

24
00:01:07.334 --> 00:01:10.800
It's not the same thing as forget my data,
remove it, and never look at it.

25
00:01:10.800 --> 00:01:14.780
But rather, let's put a hold on
what we're doing, let's validate,

26
00:01:14.780 --> 00:01:16.890
let's make sure things are good and
let's decide whether or

27
00:01:16.890 --> 00:01:19.060
not we're going to resume and go forward.

28
00:01:19.060 --> 00:01:20.110
So slightly different approach.

29
00:01:20.110 --> 00:01:24.410
So the data subject, item one, shall have
the right to obtain from the controller

30
00:01:24.410 --> 00:01:27.610
restriction of processing where one or
more of the following applies.

31
00:01:27.610 --> 00:01:30.320
Let me just scroll down so
that we can clearly see.

32
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:32.560
We have four items here, A through D.

33
00:01:34.030 --> 00:01:37.180
Accuracy of personal data is
contested by the data subject.

34
00:01:37.180 --> 00:01:39.150
We claimed something is not accurate or
valid.

35
00:01:39.150 --> 00:01:43.630
Four period enabling the controller to
verify the accuracy of the personal data

36
00:01:43.630 --> 00:01:47.390
meaning, hey stop,
I don't think that that's right, right?

37
00:01:47.390 --> 00:01:50.880
But let me give you time to go figure
whether or not it is and let's correct it.

38
00:01:50.880 --> 00:01:55.510
Again, not the same thing as erase my data
and no longer wanna play in the game.

39
00:01:55.510 --> 00:01:58.970
I no longer want you to have my
information but rather, it's incorrect.

40
00:01:58.970 --> 00:02:00.160
Let's try to fix it.

41
00:02:00.160 --> 00:02:03.160
Let's put a hold on
processing until we do.

42
00:02:03.160 --> 00:02:06.200
And let's work together,
essentially, to figure that out.

43
00:02:06.200 --> 00:02:11.040
The processing is unlawfully done, and
the data is subject opposes the erasure

44
00:02:11.040 --> 00:02:14.660
of their data, and
requests restriction of their use instead.

45
00:02:14.660 --> 00:02:16.540
So instead of saying I
want you to remove it,

46
00:02:16.540 --> 00:02:19.010
I'm going to restrict
your ability to use it.

47
00:02:19.010 --> 00:02:21.390
That is what we're saying
if it's done unlawfully.

48
00:02:21.390 --> 00:02:24.120
Remember we talked about lawful
processing standards and requirements,

49
00:02:24.120 --> 00:02:25.670
very important to be aware of that.

50
00:02:25.670 --> 00:02:28.020
The controller no longer
needs the personal data for

51
00:02:28.020 --> 00:02:30.550
the purposes of the processing, item C.

52
00:02:30.550 --> 00:02:34.070
But they are required by the data subject
for the establishment exercise or

53
00:02:34.070 --> 00:02:35.250
defense of legal claims.

54
00:02:35.250 --> 00:02:39.620
Again, we said that the right to erasure
does not apply for instance, right?

55
00:02:39.620 --> 00:02:42.850
In situations where we may
endanger the public good.

56
00:02:42.850 --> 00:02:46.940
Or we may seek to remove data but we
cannot do that because the establishment

57
00:02:46.940 --> 00:02:49.680
of the legal claim is
resting on that data, and

58
00:02:49.680 --> 00:02:52.000
as a result we cannot remove
that until that's satisfied.

59
00:02:52.000 --> 00:02:56.100
So the legitimation of that legal claim or
the defense of legal claim may have to

60
00:02:56.100 --> 00:02:59.530
stay here, or the data may have
to stay there rather as a result.

61
00:02:59.530 --> 00:03:04.390
And or D, the data subject to subjected to
processing pursuant to Article 21 we look

62
00:03:04.390 --> 00:03:07.320
at Article 21, pending
the verification whether legitimate

63
00:03:07.320 --> 00:03:10.530
grounds of the controller override
those of the data subject.

64
00:03:10.530 --> 00:03:14.020
Remember again, we stipulated that
there are certain situations where

65
00:03:14.020 --> 00:03:17.460
the controller may be able to
override the wish of the subject.

66
00:03:17.460 --> 00:03:22.100
Again for things like the public good,
the pursuance of statistical

67
00:03:22.100 --> 00:03:26.938
data gathering because of health statistic
requirements, defensive illegal claim.

68
00:03:26.938 --> 00:03:30.390
There are all these exceptions that
essentially allow us to override the wish

69
00:03:30.390 --> 00:03:34.065
of the subject for a very narrowly
defined purpose and period of time.

70
00:03:34.065 --> 00:03:37.015
But we have to play according to
those rules and be aware of them, so

71
00:03:37.015 --> 00:03:38.995
we do need to make sure
we are aware of that.

72
00:03:38.995 --> 00:03:42.965
So the data subject here,
there's some burden and responsibility.

73
00:03:42.965 --> 00:03:48.915
We as data subjects have to be clear on
when we can go to the data processor or

74
00:03:48.915 --> 00:03:53.740
controller and
request that they go ahead and

75
00:03:53.740 --> 00:03:56.690
essentially restrict
processing in some way.

76
00:03:56.690 --> 00:03:59.410
So we have to educate ourselves in other
words, right, as data subjects and

77
00:03:59.410 --> 00:04:02.890
understand this, but
the data subject is not the only party

78
00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:05.210
that has to be educated here,
as we often say.

79
00:04:05.210 --> 00:04:08.760
The data controller and processor has to
make sure they're aware of the stand or

80
00:04:08.760 --> 00:04:12.840
standards as well and understand
the potentiality of the fact that the data

81
00:04:12.840 --> 00:04:17.100
subject may make this request, and
if they do, under what circumstances.

82
00:04:17.100 --> 00:04:21.738
So item number 2, when processing has been
restricted under paragraph 1 the results

83
00:04:21.738 --> 00:04:26.121
we just talked about, such personal data
shall, with the exception of storage,

84
00:04:26.121 --> 00:04:29.170
only be processed with the data
subject's consent or for

85
00:04:29.170 --> 00:04:32.663
the establishment, exercise or
defense of legal claims, or for

86
00:04:32.663 --> 00:04:35.356
the protection of rights
of another individual.

87
00:04:35.356 --> 00:04:39.136
And or for reasons of import to
the public interest, as we talked about.

88
00:04:39.136 --> 00:04:43.751
Again, stipulating that once we put
a freeze on this data, the only time we go

89
00:04:43.751 --> 00:04:48.153
touch without the consent and
knowledge of the owner, the data subject,

90
00:04:48.153 --> 00:04:52.572
is when we have to, as it says there,
only with the exception of storage.

91
00:04:52.572 --> 00:04:55.350
Meaning that you put it in storage,
you have to maintain it in storage.

92
00:04:55.350 --> 00:04:58.910
You're backing it up, maybe you're doing
a sample restore to validate data,

93
00:04:58.910 --> 00:04:59.790
things like that.

94
00:04:59.790 --> 00:05:02.660
You may inadvertently play
with this data to do that.

95
00:05:02.660 --> 00:05:05.270
That's okay, you're not
purposely setting out to use it.

96
00:05:05.270 --> 00:05:07.500
It's just part of the normal
operation of the system.

97
00:05:07.500 --> 00:05:09.670
That's interpretative here and
that's okay.

98
00:05:09.670 --> 00:05:13.870
But in addition, anything that's required
to satisfy the public good, public safety,

99
00:05:13.870 --> 00:05:18.100
and or the defense of a legal claim,
will meet with an exception here.

100
00:05:18.100 --> 00:05:21.410
And the data subject's essentially
gonna have to opt in and say,

101
00:05:21.410 --> 00:05:23.920
yeah I guess you can use the data
because of these reasons.

102
00:05:23.920 --> 00:05:27.780
So for instance, we're a cloud service
provider, an internet service provider.

103
00:05:27.780 --> 00:05:29.000
The customer comes to us and

104
00:05:29.000 --> 00:05:33.510
says hey, right to restrict processing,
stop processing my data.

105
00:05:33.510 --> 00:05:34.590
And we freeze the data.

106
00:05:34.590 --> 00:05:37.320
And then we get sued by another customer.

107
00:05:37.320 --> 00:05:41.160
And through discovery, this customer's
data along with the customer's data that

108
00:05:41.160 --> 00:05:44.750
was frozen, becomes part of a discovery
order that goes back to the court.

109
00:05:44.750 --> 00:05:47.940
Well that data has to be given to
the court under the discovery,

110
00:05:47.940 --> 00:05:49.430
the discovery process.

111
00:05:49.430 --> 00:05:53.530
We have to notify the data subject cuz
we do have that requirement, we have

112
00:05:53.530 --> 00:05:57.670
to notify them unless the court tells us
we're not allowed to through a discovery,

113
00:05:57.670 --> 00:05:59.900
which they may do depending
on the circumstances.

114
00:05:59.900 --> 00:06:04.330
But assuming the court doesn't
specify that we cannot notify parties

115
00:06:04.330 --> 00:06:08.750
discovery through the discovery motion, we
have to notify the data subject their data

116
00:06:08.750 --> 00:06:13.000
is now in the hands of the court because
of the defense of a legal claim and

117
00:06:13.000 --> 00:06:15.020
we do have that responsibility.

118
00:06:15.020 --> 00:06:19.060
But the data subject, while they may go
to the court and seek judicial remedy

119
00:06:19.060 --> 00:06:23.280
to have their data removed from the broad
discovery net that was cast by the court

120
00:06:23.280 --> 00:06:26.232
initially, and if they can prove
just cause, they may be able to.

121
00:06:26.232 --> 00:06:28.330
If they're not party to the suit,

122
00:06:28.330 --> 00:06:30.970
if they just happen to be in
the wrong place at the wrong time,

123
00:06:30.970 --> 00:06:34.720
on the wrong server, but were not involved
with any of the activities that, maybe,

124
00:06:34.720 --> 00:06:39.400
the lawsuit is speaking to, they may be
able to seek to have their data removed.

125
00:06:39.400 --> 00:06:43.910
But unless they are successful, their
data sits as part of that dataset and

126
00:06:43.910 --> 00:06:47.870
is discoverable and as a result is
usable in a court to defend the claim or

127
00:06:47.870 --> 00:06:49.590
to prove that it is not founded.

128
00:06:49.590 --> 00:06:53.900
But either way, the request to restrict
processing is not honored as a result.

129
00:06:53.900 --> 00:06:57.470
So we do need to be aware of that and
just understand the logic of that.

130
00:06:57.470 --> 00:06:59.510
Also data subject to
obtain restrictions and

131
00:06:59.510 --> 00:07:02.610
processing pursuant to paragraph one,
item number three there,

132
00:07:02.610 --> 00:07:06.170
shall be informed by the controller before
the restriction of processing is lifted.

133
00:07:06.170 --> 00:07:10.160
As I said, we have a responsibility
to tell the data subject

134
00:07:10.160 --> 00:07:11.830
that we've done something with the data.

135
00:07:11.830 --> 00:07:14.100
But remember the court may come in and
trump that,

136
00:07:14.100 --> 00:07:18.390
as I suggested, during the discovery,
depending on the nature of the case, there

137
00:07:18.390 --> 00:07:22.770
are gag orders that may be issued and you
may not be able to tell subjects in these

138
00:07:22.770 --> 00:07:27.390
kinds of environments that their data has
been hauled into court as being examined.

139
00:07:27.390 --> 00:07:29.760
Because you may be restricted
from doing so by the court.

140
00:07:29.760 --> 00:07:32.040
Because of national security reasons or
other reasons.

141
00:07:32.040 --> 00:07:34.710
There's a whole litany of things
that may go on there these days.

142
00:07:34.710 --> 00:07:38.690
We do just need to be aware of that and
make sure that we are thinking about that.

143
00:07:38.690 --> 00:07:41.870
And that we do have this responsibility
to inform that data subject.

144
00:07:41.870 --> 00:07:43.990
But that we may not always
be able to act on that.

145
00:07:43.990 --> 00:07:48.170
Kind of a little turn or twist,
if you will, that goes on there.

146
00:07:48.170 --> 00:07:49.119
Any questions?

147
00:07:49.119 --> 00:07:53.104
>> No, that's a lot, but
it's definitely a deep dive here.

148
00:07:53.104 --> 00:07:56.137
And that's what we were looking to do
in our episode lit, so thank you for

149
00:07:56.137 --> 00:07:57.440
that, Adam.

150
00:07:57.440 --> 00:08:00.070
Do you have any final thoughts or
anything you'd like to add to that?

151
00:08:00.070 --> 00:08:01.273
>> No, I think we're good for that.

152
00:08:01.273 --> 00:08:04.291
When we're gonna come back and
talk about the right to data portability,

153
00:08:04.291 --> 00:08:06.393
just continuing down our
list of the next episode.

154
00:08:06.393 --> 00:08:10.014
So let's invite you to come back and take
a listen and look to that with us, and

155
00:08:10.014 --> 00:08:13.079
then we'll be wrapping up, I think,
with the right to object and

156
00:08:13.079 --> 00:08:16.024
then ultimately the rights
around automated provisioning.

157
00:08:16.024 --> 00:08:19.830
So we got one, two, three more,
we're gonna talk about going forward.

158
00:08:19.830 --> 00:08:22.780
But we'll wrap those up in short order, so
please come back and join us for one or

159
00:08:22.780 --> 00:08:23.460
more of those.

160
00:08:23.460 --> 00:08:27.540
>> Perfect, I don't object to that, so
we'll go ahead and sign out for this show.

161
00:08:27.540 --> 00:08:30.870
I'm sure you guys are sick
of my little jokes [LAUGH].

162
00:08:30.870 --> 00:08:32.500
I've been your host Cherokee Boost.

163
00:08:32.500 --> 00:08:34.480
>> We never get sick of you Cherokee.

164
00:08:34.480 --> 00:08:35.860
I'm Adam Gordon.

165
00:08:35.860 --> 00:08:39.613
>> See you next time
